0895260131|5.0|Notwithstanding its whimsical title, and the pop culture format of this book, it is one of the most important books you are likely ever to read.  Western culture and Western values are under attack from the followers of an amoral \\"prophet,\\" and Robert Spencer has both the spine and the facts to make this case compelling.  He shows us how the Qur'an requires armed struggle (jihad) against infidels (that would be you and me), and that this feature of Islam is not peripheral, nor are they the beliefs of a fringe element.  Killing infidels is a core value of Islam, and required by the Qur'an.  The author shows us, in text boxes, the contrast between the teachings of Jesus (love, peace, respect) and Muhammad (hate, threats, lust).  He shows how the Crusades were fundamentally defensive, and far from being a failure, may well have turned the tide in the Islamic conquest of Europe.  Spencer shatters the \\"moral equivalence\\" approach to Islam, showing that it is incapable of tolerance and that it is dedicated to evangelism by the sword.  The crux of the politically incorrect argument is that it is Islam itself which is a problem for us.  Any honest Muslim has to admit that global jihadist voilence is integral to his religion.  The core motivation for Islamic violence is rooted in the Qur'an, and there is nothing that Islamic apologists can do to obscure that fact.  And this war, dear reader, is just starting to heat up.  The attack on the World Trade Center constituted Islam's declaration of war against the West and its values, and we have no choice but to mold our foreign policy around the defeat of this enemy.<br /><br />Spencer makes \\"a few modest proposals to this end.\\"  First, \\"tie foreign aid to the treatment of non-Muslims.\\"  This means governments must end all support, material, educational, and religious, for jihad warfare, and grant full equality of rights to any non-Muslim citizens.\\"  Second, we must \\"reconfigure our global alliances on the same basis.\\"  Friendly relations with the United States [must] absolutely depend in an immediate and comprehensive renunciation of the jihad, including a reformation of schools that teach it.\\"  Third, \\"call on Muslim states to renounce sharia's expansionist imperative.\\"  Fourth, \\"undertake a full-scale \\"Manhattan Project\\" to find new energy sources, \\"so that the needed reconfiguration of our alliances can be more than just words.\\"  And, at a minimum, how about classifying Muslim groups in the US as being \\"political\\" instead of \\"religious\\" unless they renounce, in word and in deed, any intention to replace the Constitution of the United States with Islamic sharia?  This is not \\"Islamophobia,\\" friends, this is knowing the enemy.s with the United States [must] absolutely depend in an immediate and comprehensive renunciation of the jihad, including a reformation of schools that teach it.\\"  Third, \\"call on Muslim states to renounce sharia's expansionist imperative.\\"  Fourth, \\"undertake a full-scale \\"Manhattan Project\\" to find new energy sources, \\"so that the needed reconfiguration of our alliances can be more than just words.\\"  And, at a minimum, how about classifying Muslim groups in the US as being \\"political\\" instead of \\"religious\\" unless they renounce, in word and in deed, any intention to replace the Constitution of the United States with Islamic sharia?  This is not \\"Islamophobia,\\" friends, this is knowing the enemy.
B000AMJG4Y|4.0|Given that most people reviewing this movie, or rather OVA, are 1. already Final Fantasy fans, 2. watched the film before it was released in the U.S. and 3. probably wouldn't make negative comments about something they've pre-ordered months before it ever hits the retail shelves, objectivity is not very likely. However, a movie is a movie, and to be considered a great success, should greatly impress the viewer.  <br />This is no \\"Spirits Within!\\" Digital animation has come a long way in the past few years and \\"Advent Children\\" is a beautiful showcase for it, it is easy to suspend disbelief and be pulled into a film when everything looks so real - and there's no jarring \\"real\\" people or things to interrupt the experience. The animation alone makes this movie worth seeing by anyone who appreciates digital art.  <br />Viewers unfamiliar with Final Fantasy 7, the video game upon which \\"Advent Children\\" is based, be warned: there are people, scenes and conversations that will completely pass under your radar as significant. This is probably the major flaw in this film, because to fully appreciate the story line you really need to have a solid knowledge of the characters, their individual histories as well as the events that lead up to \\"Advent Children,\\" otherwise much of it may seem silly, melodramatic and ill-conceived. Viewers unfamiliar with Final Fantasy 7 should, therefore, keep it in the forefront of their minds that this movie is based upon a video game whose storyline takes more than 60 hours to tell and is considered by many the finest role playing experience ever created (my opinion isn't important, so I'm not going to share it). So does \\"Advent Children\\" only achieve 4-star status if its potentially confusing and vague storyline is excused? No, not really. The more times you watch the movie, the more things make sense because you are seeing and hearing things you may have missed the first time through.  <br />I personally watched this movie six times over thecourse of about 36 hours and was never bored. If moments arise when there's not enough to keep your mind busy, it's almost a given that your eyes will more than make up for it by feasting upon lifelike, expressive faces, detailed landscapes and incredible action sequences. It is the rare film I watch that leaves me with a feeling of stunned awe. This is one of those.
0679422714|5.0|Why is this book getting such high negatives? It is not controversial because of the loud tone in which it was written. Indeed it is written in a very Chinese way by a very Chinese author for a popular Chinese audience. Since her prose is more Kitty Kelley than Bob Woodward however, it is justifiably subject to the shallow critique that it is too personal. The three real reasons why this book has so quickly touched off a negative response are: 1) it touches upon Chinese national myth; 2) it touches some coming of age myths of many Western intellectuals of the baby-boomer generation; and 3) its vast array of new primary sources are unimpeachable.<br /><br />1) This book touches upon PRC national myth, and here I mean myth in the way an anthropologist would. Myth is a sort of marketing exaggeration of historical figures to create a broad meta-narrative for a community to share a common identity. Upon Mao's death, Deng Xiaoping turned China around 180 both in terms of policy and ideology, but political realist that he was, Deng not only maintained the Mao myth, he enhanced it. The Mao myth is that he was a selfless, fearless, workaholic, poet-intellectual whose dreamy romantic notions sometimes made a few mistakes, but by and large were brilliant applications of Marxist thought for the post-colonial world that set a backward, feudal Chinese society on the right path toward today's rapid modernization. The same public Khrushchev line about Stalin is still in vogue in today's China about Mao that \\"he was 70% correct and 30% incorrect.\\" When adult Chinese recite this school-yard quip today they are not talking about his economic policies. When Mao announced in 1949 that the \\"people of China have stood up\\" they mean stood up to foreign intervention of their sovereignty. They know the starvation numbers of The Great Leap Forward are low balled; they know that metrological records of the time show ideal weather for bumper crops; they know about the mutilation and the cannibalism of the cultural revolution; they know the literacy numbers of the 1970s are exaggerated because many in that generation of students that killed their teachers stopped learning to read. But for the Great Leap Forward, Mao is just seen as a Herbert Hoover; for the Cultural Revolution Mao is seen as General Sherman going to excesses for civil war victory. All of this is because Mao is first and foremost seen as a GEORGE WASHINGTON figure: a founding father of national independence. Since George Washington certainly didn't cut down that cherry tree, perhaps we can cut the current government of China some slack - or maybe not. Washington resigned power as a healthy man and went back to his farm. Mao wanted to be the next Joseph Stalin after Stalin died and Khrushchev was denouncing Stalinism. Like Stalin, Mao held on to power until the last blood clot.<br /><br />2) Mao's Red Guards inspired student radicalism from the Students for a Democratic Society in the US to the Red Brigade in West Germany as the Western baby boomer generation was coming of age. Now that they have grown up and vote for social democrats, they like to dream of their young idealism in comparison to the neo-liberalism of the new-left that they see as bought off by corporate America and globalization. They long for a day when there were people who got in the streets and shouted for something - however utopian. The Mao Myth matters to them as well.<br /><br />3) Chang has been able to interview many surviving relatives of the major party figures who were purged as well as locals of various battlefields to get eyewitness history. She was able to do this during a more liberal Zhang Zemin era. I doubt she could get the same access today under Hu Jintao. However, that is not where most of her bombshell conclusions originate. It was Jon Halliday's Russian language skills and systematic access to both Russian and many other Eastern European archives that has provided them with brand new primary sources. Serious historians can no longer brush aside 70 million peacetime deaths as unintended. Soviet archives document Mao's intentionality in 1958-61 mass starvation. THE BIGGEST MORSEL OF NEW HISTORY HERE IS THE DOCUMENTATION OF BOUNTIFUL AGRUCULTURAL SURPLUSS DURING THE GREAT LEAP FORWARD THAT WAS EXPORTED TO THE SOVIET UNION IN EXCHANGE FOR NUCLEAR WEAPONS AND BALISTIC MISSILE SUBMARINE TECHNOLOGY. And about that George Washington analogy from fighting a war of independence for China, Soviet archives document Mao did the opposite. The Soviets were frustrated with Mao's FAILURE to fight the Japanese (who also threatened the Soviet Union's east) so Stalin ordered him to unite with the Nationalists to FORCE a RELUCTANT Mao to fight. After 1949 China did not stand up from imperialism. Mao became a willing instrument in Soviet colonization of China, giving Stalin Manchuria and Xingjian provinces and obeying Soviet orders on Chinese internal affairs. In the Mao myth there is a breaking with the Soviets that gets painted in a sort of declaration of independence image, but the break with the Soviets was because Mao rejected Khrushchev as a liberal revisionist and wanted to continue to out-Stalin Joseph Stalin as the new leader of international Communism. The Cultural Revolution was instigated once Mao had Lin Bao in total control the PLA so that once anarchy was initiated against Mao's opponents THE ARMY WOULD DO NOTHING and Khrushchev's contacts in the CCP politburo like Liu Shaoqi could be killed at will. Soviet Documents create a very different historical Mao to the Mao of patriotic faith, yet even this account will pale in comparison to the day when the Chinese archives will be open to the public.<br /><br />Mao was right about Deng Xiaoping all along. He was a \\"Capitalist Roader.\\" Deng set in motion China's emergence from poverty yet publicly attributed his success to Mao. Unlike Mao, it was Deng who built new China. Unlike Mao, Deng tried repeatedly to withdraw from power (only to be recalled again and again by repeated successor problems that plague most undemocratic polities). One day, when China's GDP can afford a chattering class that questions national myths, the Mao myth will fade away, and Deng Xiaoping will become the real founding father of modern China.sources. Serious historians can no longer brush aside 70 million peacetime deaths as unintended. Soviet archives document Mao's intentionality in 1958-61 mass starvation. THE BIGGEST MORSEL OF NEW HISTORY HERE IS THE DOCUMENTATION OF BOUNTIFUL AGRUCULTURAL SURPLUSS DURING THE GREAT LEAP FORWARD THAT WAS EXPORTED TO THE SOVIET UNION IN EXCHANGE FOR NUCLEAR WEAPONS AND BALISTIC MISSILE SUBMARINE TECHNOLOGY. And about that George Washington analogy from fighting a war of independence for China, Soviet archives document Mao did the opposite. The Soviets were frustrated with Mao's FAILURE to fight the Japanese (who also threatened the Soviet Union's east) so Stalin ordered him to unite with the Nationalists to FORCE a RELUCTANT Mao to fight. After 1949 China did not stand up from imperialism. Mao became a willing instrument in Soviet colonization of China, giving Stalin Manchuria and Xingjian provinces and obeying Soviet orders on Chinese internal affairs. In the Mao myth there is a breaking with the Soviets that gets painted in a sort of declaration of independence image, but the break with the Soviets was because Mao rejected Khrushchev as a liberal revisionist and wanted to continue to out-Stalin Joseph Stalin as the new leader of international Communism. The Cultural Revolution was instigated once Mao had Lin Bao in total control the PLA so that once anarchy was initiated against Mao's opponents THE ARMY WOULD DO NOTHING and Khrushchev's contacts in the CCP politburo like Liu Shaoqi could be killed at will. Soviet Documents create a very different historical Mao to the Mao of patriotic faith, yet even this account will pale in comparison to the day when the Chinese archives will be open to the public. <br /> <br />Mao was right about Deng Xiaoping all along. He was a \\"Capitalist Roader.\\" Deng set in motion China's emergence from poverty yet publicly attributed his success to Mao. Unlike Mao, it was Deng who built new China. Unlike Mao, Deng tried repeatedly to withdraw from power (only to be recalled again and again by repeated successor problems that plague most undemocratic polities). One day, when China's GDP can afford a chattering class that questions national myths, the Mao myth will fade away, and Deng Xiaoping will become the real founding father of modern China.   <br />
B000002UA7|5.0|Kate Bush released \\"The Whole Story\\" in November 1986, eight years after her debut album \\"The Kick Inside\\" became a massive chart success in the United Kingdom. This album is Kate's only 'best of' to date, and will most likely remain that way for some time. It contains twelve songs, all of which feature on Kate's first five studio albums: \\"The Kick Inside,\\" \\"Lionheart,\\" \\"Never For Ever,\\" \\"The Dreaming\\" and \\"Hounds Of Love.\\" Most were big hits, a few less so, but what we can get from this collection is a very brief retrospective on the first half of Kate's career, one of the most revered and impressive in all rock and pop history. Because of this, it is an essential album for anyone remotely interested in Kate's music and as a result went straight to No.1 in the UK selling more than 1 million copies to date. The year was 1986, as previously stated, and interest in Kate's music was at an all-time high after her phenomenal comeback the previous year with the now-classic Hounds Of Love, so I think the timing was perfect for this album.<br /><br />The album opens with Kate's most famous single, \\"Wuthering Heights.\\" The song became a massive UK No.1 single in February 1978, just a month after its release. It stayed on top for four weeks and to this day is still considered one of the best songs ever written. This version is the New Vocal version, which is good but I definitely prefer the original over this. \\"Cloudbursting\\" is one of my favourite Kate songs, and one of the highlights from the Hounds Of Love album. The song has an incredible marching rhythm to it and features some stunning lyrics. It was also quite rare to hear string sections in music in this era, so Kate was producing something completely original and out there at the time, a style which has no doubt been copied endlessly in the 20 years since. The song peaked at No.20 in October 1985. \\"The Man With The Child In His Eyes\\" was Kate's second single to ever be released, and was a stunning follow up to her debut single. The song peaked at No.6 in the UK in June 1978 and is just a very moving ballad. It's quite short and doesn't even reach the third minute mark, yet the words are so profound and moving that you can't help but be drawn into this classic. Kate was merely 20 years old when this song was released, and to hear such wise words from a young mind was quite refreshing in a music world filled with one-hit wonder disco acts.<br /><br />\\"Breathing\\" is a very brilliant song, but I wouldn't really class it as one of my favourites by Kate. However, this doesn't mean it's a bad song - it's actually one of her finest in terms of production and subject matter. It peaked at No.16 in the UK in April 1980 and is about a nuclear holocaust from the perspective of a baby/foetus, who is breathing in the damaging toxic gases via her mother. The commentary around the third minute is chilling and desolate, a stark warning to the damage of the environment. \\"Wow\\" is a glittering and sparkling pure pop song that peaked at No.14 in the UK in March 1979. As far as lyrical content goes, it's not her best but the sheer power of the chorus is mesmerising. The build up to it is also pretty epic, and Kate's voice never sounded more majestic. This is an anthem for Kate's gay fanbase no doubt, and was the only major hit from her second album. \\"Hounds Of Love\\" was released in February 1986 and charted at No.18 in the UK. It was the third single from the album of the same name, and still ranks as one of Kate's finest ever singles. The belting drum beat still sounds fresh today and the mimicking of hounds barking is pure craziness: the best way to enjoy Kate. Surrender your stereotypes and pre-conceived notions and just succumb to Kate's unadulterated insanity.<br /><br />\\"Running Up That Hill\\" was the song that catapulted Kate back into the limelight and is probably her second most famous song to date. The song climbed to No.3 in the UK charts back in August 1985 and was hailed by NME magazine asthe best song ever created by a non-black British artist. Pretty impressive, don't you think? The song is totally deserving of this accolade, and many a time I find myself wondering if this is - really - my favourite song of all time. The dream-like rhythm to this song swirls around my mind like a beautiful mirage as the relentless drum beat gallops along. Beautiful vocal arrangements, eerie production and lush percussion make this song an undeniable pop classic. \\"Army Dreamers\\" is one of Kate's lesser-known songs and peaked at No.16 in the UK back in October 1980. It was the third and final single from Kate's third album, which had stormed straight to No.1 a month earlier. The song is short and sweet, quite wistful and delicate. This is contrasted by the dark subject matter of a soldier in the army who died at such a young age, and for what? This is Kate's message, it's very anti-war, and for all the right reasons. \\"Sat In Your Lap\\" was the first single to be taken from Kate's fourth album. The song itself is a frenetic three minute journey into the crazy psyche of a woman who wants to be all-knowing and knowledgeable, yet is stopped by the fact that she cannot be bothered investing the time or patience. The song perhaps sends out a message about Kate herself, who spent countless months re-working her albums until they were perfect, which became evident with her fourth album. The song charted at No.11 back in July 1981 in the UK.<br /><br />\\"Experiment IV\\" is the only song on this album not to feature on any of Kate's first five studio albums because it was a brand new song, written especially for this collection. The song peaked at No.23 in the UK in October 1986. Kate had two singles in the Top 40 at this point - the other was her stunning duet with Peter Gabriel on the ballad \\"Don't Give Up.\\" This new song is really good, and has a great percussive beat. However, it's not as good as most of the other stuff here. \\"The Dreaming\\" was released in July 1982 and peaked at a dismal No.48 in the UK a month later. I find this quite strange as apart from being a brilliant song, it was the second and final song to come off the album of the same name. The other (Sat In Your Lap) came out more than a whole year before this song. Record companies wouldn't do that nowadays! The song features Rolf Harris on digaredoo and tells the story of the aboriginal tribe in Australia, constantly at war with the civilised (modern man). The last song on this collection is \\"Babooshka,\\" one of Kate's most famous and popular songs. It peaked at No.5 in the UK back in July 1980. People less familiar with Kate's career would probably see it as a novelty track, yet it's so much more: in it, Kate disguises herself as a mystery admirer and sends love letters to her husband to test his fidelity, to see if he will respond to this 'new woman' who is so taken with him. Very crafty, the lyrics work a treat and you can't help but smile.<br /><br />OVERALL GRADE: 10/10<br /><br />When all's said and done, Kate Bush is one of the most fantastic and out-there artists to ever grace the world of music. The fact that practically no one in America knows who she is tells you something about the current state of the music industry over there, and I feel a great shame that she's not more popular. However, part of Kate's charm and appeal has always been her mystery, and after almost 30 years she is still very elusive. Unlike Madonna, Mariah and Kylie and all the other chart divas who rely on record sales to justify their success, Kate Bush is entirely her own creation. She makes music when she wants to and exactly how she wants to. Very few musicians have this privilege, so with Kate you can always be sure that what you're hearing is 100% what she wants you to hear. I hope another collection like this will follow sometime in the near future, capturing the best singles from the albums that followed this collection, \\"The Sensual World,\\" \\"The Red Shoes\\" and \\"Aerial.\\"ine as the best song ever created by a non-black British artist. Pretty impressive, don't you think? The song is totally deserving of this accolade, and many a time I find myself wondering if this is - really - my favourite song of all time. The dream-like rhythm to this song swirls around my mind like a beautiful mirage as the relentless drum beat gallops along. Beautiful vocal arrangements, eerie production and lush percussion make this song an undeniable pop classic. \\"Army Dreamers\\" is one of Kate's lesser-known songs and peaked at No.16 in the UK back in October 1980. Kate had two singles in the Top 40 at this point - the other was her stunning duet with Peter Gabriel on the ballad \\"Don't Give Up.\\" This new song is really good, and has a great percussive beat. However, part of Kate's charm and appeal has always been her mystery, and after almost 30 years she is still very elusive. She makes music when she wants to and exactly how she wants to. Very few musicians have this privilege, so with Kate you can always be sure that what you're hearing is 100% what she wants you to hear. B000002BMV|5.0|This album will always hold a special place in my heart as it was one of the very first albums that I possessed all those years back.  This together with Foreigner's \\"4\\" was the reason why I decided to pick up the guitar and to learn to love and adopt music as a hobby.  I basically wanted to sound like Neil Schon and Mick Jones for years after.  When my cassettes wore out and I decided to get cds, these 2 where among the very first albums that I got replaced.  Now, this album comes remastered for a better, cleaned up sound.  The best tracks here are \\"Don't Stop Believing\\", \\"Who's Crying Now\\", \\"Stone in Love\\", \\"Still They Ride\\" and \\"Open Arms.\\"  That's half the album already and the other tracks are decent as well except perhaps for the 2 weakest tracks, \\"Dead or Alive\\" and \\"Lay it Down.\\"  The Journey sound is a thing of beauty; the Steve Perry vocals and Neil Schon guitar sound are so unique that you just know you're listening to a Journey tune after the first few measures.  It was only when I started learning the guitar that I truly appreciated just how great a guitarist Neil Schon was.  His high speed, great technique modal scalar work is still awesome to behold after all these years.  One of the greatest albums of the 80s and very highly recommended.

0790729393|5.0|Sleepers is a movie that I never heard about before a couple weeks ago. Well I saw it and loved it. The cast on the cover draws you in right from the start but then there's the movie. Absolutely brilliant. <br />Right from the start, you know that it's going to be sad, disturbing and one hell of a powerful movie. The plot centers around four boys that are sent to the Wilkenson Home for  <br />Boys after a prank in Hell's Kitchen goes horribly wrong. But the guards there are perverts that abuse them, in so many ways.  <br />This ruins their entire lives. But when they have a chance for revenge latter on in life, they take it and a court room trial comes next to determine their fates.  <br />The movie is gripping, powerful and haunting. What makes it even more scary is that its' based on a book written by one of the 4 boys, based on reality.  <br />The acting is great with Robert DeNiro stealing the show! Kevin Bacon is creepy and Dustin Hoffman adds a lot! <br />Ultimately, this movie is one of my favorites of all time. The DVD treatment is lousy though. There are 2 side to the DVD that splits the movie in 2! What the heck? <br />But you can get it for a low price and you'll really enjoy it even though it's so hard to watch. It makes your mind think a lot...and makes you wonder what you would do in their position. Would you kill for revenge? It's so hard to think about these thinks and the fact that it's based on a true story makes it all the scarier.  <br />Sleepers is a masterpiece, a must see movie that will haunt you for days.

034547581X|4.0|I would make this required reading for all potential leaders. Moore is not anti-war, but not pro-war, either; he recognizes it needs to happen, but he wants us to see it in detail. The first two thirds of this book are factual descriptions of the battles at Ia Drang in 1965, intelligently using monologues by those involved for paragraphs and even pages at a time. It is the battle through the words of those who were there, and in its detail and portrayal of context it is not only highly accurate but charged with a vivid sense of what the experience must have been like. After this, the authors speak on the political context of the battle, and then follow the families of American dead afterwards. To read that chapter takes a bit of determination. Gen Westmoreland gets lampooned and Chinese intervention get mentioned in the wrap-up after that, which is as tightly written as the rest, and includes criticism of American political methods and aims in the war. I would recommend this book to anyone interested in history.

B00005JOHI|5.0|Let's say up front that the 2005 Pride and Prejudice, starring Keira Knightley as Lizzie and Matthew Macfadyen as Darcy, is not meant to be a 100% accurate adaptation of the book. Trimmed down to a mere 2 hours, the story had to be cut up a great deal. It's also set in the late 1700s - when a 21 year old Jane Austen first thought up the story, instead of the early 1800s, when 38 year old Jane finally finished and published the work.<br /><br />That all being said, this movie is amazingly well done. In some ways, it's much more realistic than other depictions of the story. Many movie versions of P&P have the characters set up almost like cartoon characters. They are squeaky clean, their world is pristine, and they float through it. While many in the early 1800s had nice manners, their life was certainly not Lysol-clean!<br /><br />It was really nice, then, to see the quiet English town actually appear like a live, working English town. The story clearly has Lizzie show up with a ton of mud on her skirts after hiking across miles of marshy English countryside. In most movie versions, that means there's a hint of brown on her trimly pressed outfit. In this version, it's much more realistic. I've hiked around England - you get muddy!<br /><br />In some ways, the movie is like \\"Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead\\" - where you hear snippets of dialogue and if you know the story, you realize what is going on in the background. It really does cater strongly to people who know the full story well and don't need all the details filled in. Again, this is to be expected given there are only 2 hours of story here. Many of the backgrounds and details are shaved or missing. The characters, however, are still quite solid and fully done.<br /><br />Lizzie and Darcy of course are the main characters here, and they shine with a freshness that is really great. These aren't \\"story members\\" just walking through and trading barbs. You really get a sense that Lizzie is a flesh and blood woman who is feeling the powerful loves, hates, and other emotions. Darcy feels the same passions, reigning them in under his family training. Many of the scenes with the two characters are just amazing - when they are dancing, when they are in the gazebo in the rain.<br /><br />In some ways, I even feel the movie adds to the story, helping to elucidate scenes that might otherwise go over viewers' heads. Often, Charlotte's choosing to marry Collins is seen as a quiet, calm decision made without any emotion at all. I always found this depiction to be unrealistic. In this version, Charlotte makes it clear that this wouldn't be her ideal choice - but what else can she do? Does she really want to be a spinster and burden on her family? She's full of angst, but she's done the best she could with a bad situation.<br /><br />Also, it's always bugged me that in some movie versions, they made a big deal about Lizzie's \\"revelation\\" in Darcy's home that she really would have been happy as his wife. She feels this way because his servants love him so much, a sign of a truly \\"gentle man\\". However, some movies turn it into a gold-digging Lizzie looking around saying \\"Wow, I could have lived HERE\\". I was very happy that in this movie, Lizzie is touched by the gorgeous sculpture and the way Darcy's sister loves him.<br /><br />Even some of the minor characters are done amazingly well. I love Sutherland and Dench, they are simply wonderful. Others are less stellar - Wickham springs to mind as being an \\"elf lookalike\\" - but it's hard to expect every single cast member to be stunning.<br /><br />Highly recommended as a must-see for anyone who loves a romantic story full of incredibly fun dialogue.woman who is feeling the powerful loves, hates, and other emotions. Darcy feels the same passions, reigning them in under his family training. Many of the scenes with the two characters are just amazing - when they are dancing, when they are in the gazebo in the rain.<br /><br />In some ways, I even feel the movie adds to the story, helping to elucidate scenes that might otherwise go over viewers' heads. Often, Charlotte's choosing to marry Collins is seen as a quiet, calm decision made without any emotion at all. I always found this depiction to be unrealistic. In this version, Charlotte makes it clear that this wouldn't be her ideal choice - but what else can she do? Does she really want to be a spinster and burden on her family? She's full of angst, but she's done the best she could with a bad situation.<br /><br />Also, it's always bugged me that in some movie versions, they made a big deal about Lizzie's \\"revelation\\" in Darcy's home that she really would have been happy as his wife. She feels this way because his servants love him so much, a sign of a truly \\"gentle man\\". However, some movies turn it into a gold-digging Lizzie looking around saying \\"Wow, I could have lived HERE\\". I was very happy that in this movie, Lizzie is touched by the gorgeous sculpture and the way Darcy's sister loves him.<br /><br />Even some of the minor characters are done amazingly well. I love Sutherland and Dench, they are simply wonderful. Others are less stellar - Wickham springs to mind as being an \\"elf lookalike\\" - but it's hard to expect every single cast member to be stunning.<br /><br />Highly recommended as a must-see for anyone who loves a romantic story full of incredibly fun dialogue.

B00005JLPK|2.0|At the risk of appearing \\"artistically uncouth,\\" I must admit (in hushed tones) that I did not find Frida interesting enough to even see it through to the end.  Urged by several acquaintances to experience this movie not only on the merit of its emotionally stirring story but for its visual effects as well, I was eager to give it a try.  I did feel drawn in at the beginning of the movie as Frida struggled through a harrowing recuperation from her injuries in a bus accident and discovered her talents in art in the process.  But not long after she began to get serious about art as a career and met up with Rivera, I began to feel that I was merely an observer to an endless parade of the artist's questionable personal actions, provided with little or no understanding as to the underlying reasons for those actions.  I think it was this lack of depth that caused my interest to wane.  The fact that there is little character development or even character understanding in Frida is not surprising since this is often the case with real-life stories.  But it does not make for a satisfying movie experience if this is what you enjoy.  As for the visual effects - supposedly a treat for the senses - I didn't find them particularly noteworthy.  If you're interested in a glimpse into Frida Kahlo's life story as an artist that you admire, then you probably won't be disappointed because the movie brings her story to life, but if you are looking for some level of emotional intimacy with the main character, you may very well be.
0553213105|5.0|For those who are able to set aside their modern-day literature expectations and experiences, reading Pride and Prejudice is a wonderful, even riveting experience. I admit that if I had been assigned this novel in high school or college, reading it would have been an ordeal and I would have cursed the teacher or professor all the way through. Maybe it's my relatively advanced age or the fact that I just saw the movie that caused my mind to open and made Pride and Prejudice difficult to put down and exhilarating to read. Besides the seemingly stilted language of the period, Austen leaves much, including emotions and dialogue, to the imagination. The former lessens more and more as the pages go by and the latter actually makes the story more sensual and exciting. I found myself rereading chapters for the sheer enjoyment of trying to get in the minds of Mr. Darcy, Lizzy, Jane, Mr. Bennett, Mr. Collins and all the others. The characters are unforgetable and I will revisit them from time to time during the rest of my life. Today Pride and Prejudice definitely makes my top ten list of novels to take to a desert island.
B0001ADAVK|3.0|Mona Lisa Smile is more about the mores of the east coast elite than art history as its name might imply.  As with many real life situations, conclusions are not drawn with crystal clarity, tending to make the viewer feel a lack of  closure.  And all of the characters do not necessarily grow as a result of their experiences; instead, they merely become aware of their own limitations.  Julia Roberts succeeds in playing the multidimensional role of the art history instructor by occasionally allowing the viewer to see the nonconforming liberal underneath the quiet and reserved historian.  The supporting actresses who play the roles of the students shine in their performances with the exception of Julia Stiles who just can't seem to sound natural in her elocution-smooth accent.  The faithful recreation of  the 1950s culture of this elite group, including fashions, home d&eacute;cor, TV programs, dances, and traditional activities of the college keep the viewer interested, as does a dynamic plot.  The main value in Mona Lisa Smile lies in the understanding of a generation of women who were taught to believe that marriage and housewifery was the only meaningful option for women of their class and that it was guaranteed to provide fulfillment.

0452282152|5.0|In Girl with a Pearl Earring, Chevalier paints such an intimate and believable portrait of a girl whose fascination with and devotion to her \\"master\\" is so complete, that the reader cannot help but admire her and yet pity her at the same time.  Told in a simple yet powerful narrative, Chevalier traces Griet's growing attraction for the painter as well as the complex relationships within the entire Vermeer household and her own.  Each character sketch is a work of art:  the wife whose insecurity makes her self-centered and shallow, the perceptive yet hard-boiled mother-in-law who makes it her business to do what it takes to ensure their financial security, the simple-minded maid who takes offense easily and doesn't hesitate to punish those who offend her, the brother who is so disillusioned with his apprenticeship that he becomes reckless in the pursuit of pleasure, and the artist, who is willing to sacrifice a young girl's honor and livelihood as well as his own relationship with her, to become a successful painter.  Chevalier helps us to understand the private life of an exceedingly bright and sensitive but very quiet young girl who is surprisingly astute in her evaluations of the people she comes in contact with but yet nave where her strongest affections lie.  Chevalier skillfully traces Griet's growing attraction for her \\"master\\" that develops into a bond she cannot willingly relinquish even when it threatens to destroy her chances for future happiness.  She also addresses the moralistic attitudes of the times that left young women of Griet's station in life with few choices if they were unlucky enough to attract the attentions of the wrong sort of man.  In addition to the complex personal relationships that Chevalier brings to life, she succeeds in creating a convincing portrayal of daily life in 17th-century Holland as well as the process of painting from the preparation of the paints to the finishing touches, through rich and sensual visual imagery. Overall, Girl with a Pearl Earring is an absorbing and evocative novel that is sure to give the reader a deeper understanding of the bond that can develop between two people who share a similar way of looking at the world as well as an insight into the emotions felt by those who lack the freedom or the desire to reveal them.Girl with a Pearl Earring is an absorbing and evocative novel that is sure to give the reader a deeper understanding of the bond that can develop between two people who share a similar way of looking at the world as well as an insight into the emotions felt by those who lack the freedom or the desire to reveal them.

B000002VQQ|4.0|In the 1970's I owned two of Patti Smith's vinyl releases, 'Wave', and this disc, her debut LP, released in 1975.  Though artist's such as Smith were part-punk, part-post psychedelia, the heir's apparent to hippie-inspired rock and roll, they still maintained a direct connection to the Baby Boom Generation, as evidenced by the non-Patti Smith compositions chosen for this disc, Van Morrison's 'Gloria', Chris Kenner's 'Land of a Thousand Dances' (previously recorded by Wilson Pickett), and on the remastered CD, Pete Townshend's 'My Generation'.  Of course Patti Smith's versions, though possessing all the intensity and passion of the original versions (and then some), also lack the relative innocence of those renditions.  In part, Smith's interpretations serve notice that that crown of rock's royalty has been passed to a new genre, if not a new generation.  That new generation, perhaps more of an addendum to the Baby Boom Generation, included a greater openness to alternative lifestyles, as Smith sings love songs to 'Gloria' and 'Kimberly' in her uncompromising manner.    I originally purchased 'Horses' due to a dearth of quality recordings being produced by my old standby's, such as Eric Clapton, Stephen Stills, Neil Young and Steve Winwood.  At the time, Smith's version of 'Gloria' was receiving considerable FM airplay, and she seemed to be on the cusp of something new and exciting.  While I wasn't enthused by the recording as a whole, it certainly was loud, raw, explicit, and challenging, qualities my previous favorites had apparently forsaken.  Smith's singing style was also completely unique, and despite the fact her lyrics were at times incomprehensible, it was always a treat to hear her deliver them.  I'm much more enthused by Smith numbers that possess a fast tempo and hungry, driving guitar work, such as the opening track, 'Gloria', promised for the rest of the disc.  Unfortunately you have to work through the punk-reggae of 'Redondo Beach', and the punk-bluesof 'Birdland' to get to the more serious pile driving excursions of 'Free Money', 'Kimberly', and 'Break It Up'.  These three tracks, in addition to 'Gloria', are to me the meat of the album.  Although the slower numbers are outnumbered on the disc, since 'Birdland' and 'Land' time out at about nineteen minutes, they claim much of the available recording time.  The original closer, 'Elegie', is also a slow track, timing out at 2:41.  Smith added a bonus track, an unremarkable 3:16 live version of 'My Generation' to this remastered package.    Patti Smith appeals to a more artistically aware and elite crowd than rock and roll normally attracts.  She spent time delivering her poetry without musical support prior to 1975, and even on this disc at times reads rather than sings her writings.  Nevertheless, Smith relies on a bare bones backing band of piano, bass, lead guitar, and drums, and the instrumental backing is simplistic as well.  I never found Patti Smith's brand of performing as something I would consistantly listen to, but it did find a niche in my collection, appealing as an alternative rather than a staple.  I guess society as a whole possessed the same view, as only one Patti Smith song, 'Because the Night', ever cracked into the Top-40 (#13 in 1978).  While I considered three stars, four is perhaps more representative of 'Horses' overall value.
B00005JO1Y|4.0|The arrival of \\"King Kong\\", one of the years most anticipated films, gives movie goers a big box office spectacle just in time for the holidays.  A lot of overwhelming expectations ride on this film and its director, especially since it is a remake of a beloved classic that most everyone has seen.  The question is this----Is Peter Jackson successful in remaking this movie?  I think the answer is yes.<br /><br />Although there are some problems with the film, I think overall Jackson did a nice job of bringing this story to the big screen.  Its obvious that this film was a labor of love.  Naomi Watts is perfect as the lovely Ann Darrow, the beauty who steals the heart of the beast.  Jack Black, the film director Carl Denim, adds humor to the story and Adrien Brody provides the human love interest for Ann Darrow.  But the true star of the movie is, of course, Kong.  And Jackson succeeded at humanizing the big ape, making the viewer realize that Kong has been taken out of his element.  Probably for me, the best moments in the film are the moments that Kong spends alone with Ann Darrow.  From the time that she dances for him and he sees her as a small, moving toy to the final scenes where she sees him in the street and the inevitable climb of the Empire State Building---these are the moments that make the movie.  The scenes are tender and, for me, are really the best moments in Jackson's remake.  I especially liked the scene where Kong with Darrow, discovers snow in the park---a nice touch.<br /><br />And for those who like action, there is plenty once their ship, the Venture, runs ashore Skull island.  From T-Rexes, huge long necks dinosaurs, giant insects and evil natives, the adventurors face a gamit of challenges, including Kong himself.  The special effects are good and keep the action flowing.<br /><br />Now for the problems.  To me the first hour is just too long.  I think the introduction of the characters and their storylines seemed to take forever.  My 8 year old nephew actually fell asleep for the first hour but awakened once Kong made his appearance. Also, as much as I enjoyed Skull island, I think the time spent there could have been edited a little.  The film score was okay but I think could have been a little more dramatic.<br /><br />Overall, however, I think this is a film you will enjoy.  Its a great popcorn flick and definitely should be see on the big screen.  Some of the scenes will be too intense for small children but my 8 year old niece and nephew enjoyed the film (the last two hours)---any younger and they may get bored or scared.  I look forward to seeing the extras that Jackson gives us with the dvd release next year!year old nephew actually fell asleep for the first hour but awakened once Kong made his appearance. Also, as much as I enjoyed Skull island, I think the time spent there could have been edited a little. I look forward to seeing the extras that Jackson gives us with the dvd release next year!

However, after I finally made it through (its 250+ pgs), I realized that a lot of the content is bogus and not realistic in a \\"regular\\" lifestyle (unless your dad fed you into Yale and you cruised your way to a Harvard MBA, and then could afford to finally ask yourself what you actually want to do). I do love how some authors pride themselves on their humble upbringing, but yet somehow acsend to Ivy League undergrad & grad school through a favor. Anyways getting back to my point, do not buy the book - I recommend sitting at Barnes, Borders, etc. and reading the first 60-80 pgs (max). If you're looking for some motivation/tactics of networking, you might find it within that portion. The rest 150+ pgs just beats a dead horse. I'm a slow reader and the small amount of time it takes to hit the first 60 pages isn't worth paying for.
B000068PQ0|5.0|Look.  I don't write reviews.  But I'm tired of everyone saying that this album is pretty good, but not as good as the Soft Bulletin, their \\"obvious masterpiece.\\" <br /> <br />I got into the Lips several years back after hearing Transmissions from the Satellite Heart.  A great rock record.  Then onto Clouds Taste Metallic and the Soft Bulletin.   <br />All those albums are great, every single one.  The Soft Bulletin really takes it there, though. <br /> <br />That being said, I was looking forward to giving Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots a try.  And I gotta say, I didn't think much of it.  Cluttered, confusing, it didn't have the hooks of their other albums that drew me in.  After a couple of listens I told someone \\"Well, Yoshimi Part I and Do You Realize are pretty good, but as a whole the album's not really worth getting.\\"   <br /> <br />But there is something to be said for patience.  Like many of the most rewarding things in life, this album needs time to ferment in your brain.  After putting it back on the shelf, a year later I picked it up again.  And again.  And again.  And I have this to say: This is probably my favorite album of all time.  I own somewhere around  500 albums.  I like many genres of music, from rock to country to hip hop to classical to electronic.  And I don't love any album as much I love this one.   <br /> <br />Listen to it a few times.  Take a break.  Then, one night, get high (or not), turn off the lights and lay down and listen to Yoshimi Battle the Pink Robots on the best pair of headphones you can find.  This album is so beautiful, sad, and uplifting.   The production is incredible.  The sound of the bass - what album has better sounding bass?? - plodding the course of many of the tracks cuts through to your brain, rhythmic and melodic simultaneously.  The guitars, the electronics, the drums both synthetic and live banging heavy and aggressive when needed, soft and sparse when not.  What ultimately brings this album to the top is the lyrics.  The power of the song \\"The Gash\\" from the Soft Bulletin is spread across almost every track on Yoshimi.   There are people who criticize this album for having simplistic or cliche'd lyrics.  But the kind of universal truth in lyrics like \\"I'm a man, not a boy/and there are things you can't avoid/you have to face them/when you're not prepared to face them\\" will draw in anyone who is genuinely trying to make a good go of it in this nutty world. <br /> <br />Also, as a musician, there's no album that is as intimidating and inspiring.

B0009F9O6M|4.0|Years ago (before the Internet) I was looking at a book about my favorite band called \\"Genesis: From One Fan To Another\\" by Armando Gallo. Inside there was a reproduction of was an old Charisma records tour billing from 1972 that included Van der Graaf Generator and Lindisfarne. Trying to determine what kind of environment could have produce the singular style of Genesis, I bought a Van der Graaf compilation CD.    At first, I thought they were a poor man's Genesis. Their keyboardist wasn't in the same league as Tony Banks and who was that horrible singer? But, once I listened to the drummer, my experience changed.    H To He was the first full-length VdGG album I bought. Peter Hammill's dark (and frankly depressing) lyrics are redeemed by the sharp and aggressive attack of drummer Guy Evans and saxophonist David Jackson. Killer is one of the standout cuts and is reminiscent of early King Crimson. With their cutting lyrics and superb musicianship, VdGG are one of those groups that stays with you forever.    [DW]

B000001DTM|5.0|\\"Achtung Baby\\" has a special place in my life. At the same time U2 were unveiling their reinvented selves to the world, I had moved to Los Angeles to reinvent myself as a writer. I was driving to the office I worked at, and K-Rock in Los Angeles announced they were about to world-debut the brand new song from the new U2 album. This being morning on the 101, it meant that I was sitting for extended periods of time...and the heady buzz of \\"The Fly\\" came on the speakers.<br /><br />It was a good thing we were in gridlock, because I would have needed to pull over. I was that amazed. Bono had suddenly made the leap from charismatic flag waving anthem belter to charismatic rock god (\\"it's no secret that a conscious can sometimes be a pest...\\"). It was such a stunning transformation that - on the day \\"Achtung Baby\\" was released - I ran out on my lunch break to find a copy. The album thoroughly lived up to and even beyond my expectations. U2 had redefined themselves for the new decade, and had also thrust themselves into a new level of musical awareness.<br /><br />It came with not just the incredible cohesion of this album, but in the stunning songs. \\"Mysterious Ways\\" found the band exploring funk. \\"Zoo Station\\" was the earlier foray into the electronics that would burst out on \\"Zooropa\\" and the ballads were some of Bono's best lyrics yet. It culminates in \\"Achtung Baby's\\" centerpiece, the astonishing \\"One.\\" Correspondingly bitter, aching, resentful and hopeful, it is easily one of the best songs of the 90's. It takes the traditional themes of spiritual wanderlust and frustration and wraps it up in the conciseness of a lyric like:<br /><br />\\"You say love's a temple, love's a higher law.<br /><br />You ask me to enter, then you make me crawl.\\"<br /><br />\\"Achtung Baby\\" was the album that lifted U2 from their already lofty position in rock and set their path for the new decade. In my library, this is a desert island record.

0553801503|3.0|The latest book in A Song of Ice and Fire series appears to be a meandering exercise in following side characters which adds little to the progress of the overall story line. I have loved all the other books, re-read them , kept well clear of the spoilers. But having just finished this one, and although George R.R. Martin still writes as well as in his other works (hence the three stars), I feel cheated.   <br /> <br />Nothing much happens in a book of 800 pages: Cersei becomes a main character but she is shallow and obviously self destructive so her progress does not keep me awake at night; Sansa grows up a little, same with Arya; Jon stays where he was in the previous book; Bran has disappeared; Samwel takes a journey in which he meets some colourful characters; and there is no further mention of any of the historical story lines e.g. about Rhaegar, Lyanna, the tournament of Harrenhall. The only characters which were further developed were Jaime, who having lost a hand cannot continue to be the golden ruler of the roost of knights and Brienne, the ugly maid warrior who (somewhat predictably, as the same thing happened to Tyrion) only becomes uglier although her character is developed nicely.  And it all ends in suspense, somewhat like a weekly TV serial, except that it comes in three yearly installments. <br /> <br />I would have much preferred to see the story with the main characters from the first three books continue and progress in this book and (if one can have a wish-list) some of the riddles if not answered then at least further explored. Sure, it is difficult to invent a whole new world so I have no problem at all with using it to generate any number of books. However I believe that George R.R. Martin could produce better work by writing a separate series or one-off books which deal with new characters or further explore the non-primary characters, rather than just adding more detail and more characters and going nowhere. <br /> <br />I would recommend not to buy the book if you can get it from a library or from a friend, for the next one I will try to read it before spending any money.
B00004VWAF|4.0|That may seem harsh but it's the truth. Take the title of the instance; On the Corner. What was \\"on the corner\\" for any major city in 1972? An abstract mix of sounds, but with a common groove, yes? Well there you go. Take his stated influnces for this piece, Sly and Stockhausen, have you listened in depth to those two composers? Groove and the use of sound verse silence. If you have these three pieces; what a corner in 1972 sounds like, Sly and Stockhausen... then you have On the Corner. I'm sorry that somebody in 2005 writes what amounts to \\"getting it\\" for a creation of 1972, but that's life. It's abstract music people, if all you want is someone to put out one album after another that sounds exactly the same then you just don't \\"get it\\". This is not music for people who don't like abstract reality, it clicked for me right away. I don't love it nor hate it, I like it. It will influence me. I'm sorry that Miles isn't around to hear this, but he wouldn't care anyway. I don't feel sorry for people stuck in one groove of music, but you must realize how limited that is. Miles was beyond Jazz, can't you \\"get it\\"? Jazz, like all labels, is a limit. If you don't like it, that's cool. See? I *really* respect Miles now, he's not \\"just\\" a jazz player to me anymore after hearing this several times over. Maybe this is just music for musicians, but that happens. I'm not sure people without exposure to music theory can really grasp what is \\"On the Corner\\".
0446310786|5.0|In this unforgettable story, a woman recounts a part of her childhood in a small Alabama town during the Depression.  Her father, Atticus Finch, was the local lawyer, an upright and wise man, who raised her brother Jem, and herself, Scout.  The summer before Scout started school, their idyllic lives were full of imagination and adventure; their games often concerned their reclusive neighbor \\"Boo\\" Radley, and how best to make him to \\"come out.\\"  Scout began the first grade and found many things confusing, not the least of which was her teacher's admonition not to read any more with her beloved father.  Summer came again, and with it, a controversial trial that would affect the children's lives forever:  A black man was accused of raping a white woman and, despite pressure from racist townsfolk, Atticus was defending him.<br /><br />The straightforward and innocent rural dialogue absolutely deserves to be read aloud to be enjoyed and appreciated.  I often found myself rereading passages again and again, just because they were worded so perfectly.  The children's adventures were very easy to picture in my mind, and the narration had a truth about it that was simple, inspiring and touching.  This tale of childhood innocence teaches lessons about tolerance and kindness, and paints one of the most remarkable characters in literature, the courageous and loving Atticus Finch.  This is a novel to be savored and enjoyed over and over again.  It is wonderful.<br /><br />Kona
B00007L4MJ|5.0|\\"Between the brain that plans and the hands that build there must be a mediator.\\" This famous quote by Thea von Harbou perfectly summarizes the main theme of the film.<br /><br />The story takes place in 2026 in the city of Metropolis, where the society is divided into two groups: the elite ruling class (brain that plans) and the working class (the hands that build). The way the city of Metropolis is represented is expressionistic in the way that the two different layers, the underground and the above ground, reflect the emotions as well as the living conditions of the people living there. In the above ground, the elite class lives a luxurious, happy life; entertain themselves in the \\"eternal gardens,\\" the skyscrapers rising to the sky represent the rising of upper class in wealth and power. Whereas, the workers live in the gloomy labyrinths of the underground, which is the power center of the city; they are stuck in dim buildings that are surrounded by huge machinery. There is no mediator between these two groups until one person from the ruling class dares to go underground; he is terrified with what he sees.<br /><br />The visual features used in the film are highly impressive especially when the technological conditions of the German film industry in the 1920s are considered. The symbolical usage of lights and shadows as well as the music contribute to the plot, and these features artistically enrich the film. The mechanical and cold atmosphere of the city is successfully represented through architecture. The gestures and mimics of the actors in Metropolis is one of the things that you cannot find in Hollywood films. This is absolutely a masterpiece of silent films.<br /><br />Lang's film has many levels; one can approach it politically, in terms of class dynamics or in terms of gender and the representation of woman or its association with the evil, etc. The characters are brilliantly used for conveying the sub-themes in the film. You have to see this multidimensional master piece of science fiction; it is a feast for the eye, for the ear and the mind!

B000000H57|5.0|In honor of winter's presense surrounding me, I'd like to discuss one of my favorite \\"seasonal\\" albums, Type O Negative's October Rust. And by seasonal, I mean it encompasses all seasons--just take the cover art, which by each song pairs photo of the woods in different conditions, different lights. October Rust is the most melodic of Type O's works to date, and as a result, the favorite of many fans. It may be softer than  their other albums, but still retains some aggression and lots of haunting through its ambience, deep guitar bellows, and Pete Steele's bottom-of-the-well bass vocals.<br /><br />Type O Negative has this way of merging sarcasm and beauty. It's just an ever-apparent characteristic of their style. In October Rust, they start out by playing a little gag on us, but before we have too much time to respond, we are immediately thrust into \\"Love You to Death,\\" a song of ultimate gothic romance. The romance continues with \\"Be My Druidness,\\" a tale of pure lust. The sun is alive and burning in \\"Green Man,\\" a song about the human condition through the seasons. Next, if you're dreaming of a black Christmas, you have to experience \\"Red Water.\\" It's  not a song of Christmas morning, but rather Christmas mourning. The mood and the transitions in this song are amazing. \\"My Girlfriend's Girlfriend,\\" the most catchy tune on the album, is all about kink and unconventional romance. \\"Die With Me,\\" a song about the departure of a loved one, is softer with beautiful crescendos. \\"Burnt Flowers Fallen,\\" though minimal in lyrics, carries some great moments, though one of the weaker tracks. Themes of burning continue into \\"In Praise of Bacchus, where we have wounded images of New York City--a song that intensifies the most at the end. \\"Cinnamon Girl\\" takes the basic melody of the Neil Young version and twists it into something completely Type O. \\"Wolf Moon\\" carries moods of isolation in the deep woods; of the warning and spell-like quality of a full moon shining upon darkness. Tortured sensuality drifts through \\"Haunted,\\" the final and darkest track.tured sensuality drifts through \\"Haunted,\\" the final and darkest track.

0307276902|3.0|I've just finished reading \\"A million Little Pieces\\". It is a beautiful story. It is a painful story. But most importantly, it is a DANGEROUS story.  <br /> <br />  James Frey rivetingly captures the emotional roller-coaster ride that is addication and rehabilitation. His personal experiences at the center and his character studies ring authentic to this reader. I experienced much of what he went through(sans the love interest) with my own stay at a private rehabilitation center in New Jersey, some four years ago.  <br /> <br />   Frey manages to sucsessfully capture the horror, the pain, and eventually, even the slow, step by tiny step,process of recovery, but he fails repeatedly to identify the benchmarks in his recovery, and more importantly,he fails to indentify the true catylists that were so instrumentel in helping him to achieve those bench marks. <br /> <br />    I applaud James Frey for his unique recovery, and his years of subsequent sobrierty, but I worry that his book will inadvertanly send the wrong message to those that need it the most.There is a little narcissism in us all, and people with addictive personalities have more than thier fair share. Mr.Frey's memoir is frought with narcissism and therein lies its danger.  <br />   After reading his account one is led to believe that it was his will, perserverence, and a little help from the \\"Tao Te Ching\\" that made it possible for him to recover.The rehab staff and fellow patients that surrounded him were little more than suopportive sidekicks and distractions. <br />   Now here is where it gets tricky. As for A.A. and the twelve steps, he gives them little credence or respect throughout his recovery and at times he is  simply downright nasty in his critisism of the program. He pokes fun at it and at those who believe in it and are trying to help him. <br /> <br /> Here in lies the problem with his memoir, and also why the book is dangerous. Each step of the way as he begins to recover, he states that hehis doing it all on his own and then he takes pot- shots at the twelve-step program, repeatedly telling the reader that the program is just trading addictions, and it is not for him. But in reality, he is doing exactly what he denies and abhors. By his own described actions, he is unwittingly,doing the very steps that he denies so vehemently. <br /> <br />  His descison to stay is the first step. His acceptance of Leonard and the Tao are steps two and three. His admsiions to his family, to Lilly, and to his friends is the fourth step asnd the fifth step is the climax of the book where he writes out his list and frees his soul.He discards the notion of a higher power throughout the book. Well, if leonard, Lilly and the Tao don't represent his higher power, I don't know what does.  <br /> <br />    I am glad Jim Frey remains sober today and I am also glad that his book had become so popular, but I can't help but worry that somewhere out there in thes big world of ours there is someone reading his book and looking for guidence with their own addiction and they will not be able to follow his path. Very few can. A.A. worked for him, whether he chooses to admit it or not and it has worked for millions of others. Less than 2 percent of addicts are able to do what James Frey claims he has done. Readers, be inspired by his road to recovery, but please don't try and follow his proclaimed path. it won't work.  <br />

B0002F6AH0|5.0|This is an extremely valuable presentation of both some of the causes, and the conduct of the battles, of the greatest war the world has ever known.  This is vital history to which every educated person should be exposed, lest we repeate history for want of knowing it.<br /><br />The World At War features some absolutely magnificent analysis of World War Two.  Particularly good were the segments that dealt with the rise of Hitler and Nazism (\\"A New Germany,\\" \\"Hitler's Germany\\") and the battles on the Eastern Front (\\"Red Star\\").  I would say that this series does have a notable British orientation in that the War in the Pacific is emphasized far less than the European Theater.  Further, the battles of Singapore, and the struggle around the Burma Road get almost as much analysis as America's drive across the Central Pacific, which was the real center of gravity of the Pacific War.  These are minor quibbles, however; this is a fine series.<br /><br />A few criticisms.  The segment dealing with the allies' relations with Stalin immediately following victory features (I swear to God) an interview with -- Alger Hiss!-- who is presented only as a \\"State Department Official\\" or somesuch.  Hiss, of course, was jailed for denying falsely, under oath, that he was a Soviet/Communist agent.  This film makes no mention of the rather critical detail that not only was Hiss, as a Soviet agent, perhaps a bit pro-Soviet in his bias, but he was also one of those charged with briefing President Truman.  This seems to me to be a rather unforgivable lapse in historical perspective, but I digress.<br /><br />The above quibbles are minor in comparison to this overall very superb historical achievement.  This is a wonderful presentation of the war, thoughtful and at times profound.  The DVDs are nicely packaged for easy access to any particular episode, and my copy seemed to be perfect in every respect.  Viewers over 45 (me!) will need reading glasses to read the volume numbers on the DVD covers, however.  I guess they couldn't find any smaller type.<br /><br />This is a wonderful series, head and shoulders above most presentations dealing with the Second World War.  It will an asset to which the discerning viewer will return many times.DVD covers, however.  I guess they couldn't find any smaller type. <br /> <br />This is a wonderful series, head and shoulders above most presentations dealing with the Second World War.  It will an asset to which the discerning viewer will return many times.

However, she puts the cocky and supercilious in their place while still maintaining her own dignity.  In some ways she is very naive and unworldly, but in dealing with human nature she is wise beyond her years. We can all learn a thing or two from Mme. Ramotswe.

B00002MHS1|5.0|There have been a number of different versions of this CD.  There is a US, remastered version that does not have the live bonus track (but keeps the bad bonus studio tracks).  It is less than half the price of this \\"Import\\" CD.      There are five bonus tracks on this album.  The studio tracks I Just Want You To Know and Sitting Here, Thinking Of My Love are pretty bad.  They are nothing like Traffic has done.  They sound like they were meant to be AM radio hits.  What's worse, is that I Just Want You To Know is stuck right in the middle of the original material.  It really upsets the flow of the original album.    The three live bonus tracks are an introduction to the band, a 7 minute Who Knows What Tomorrow May Bring and a 12 minute Glad, with following Freedom Ride hacked off.  As the liner notes explain, Traffic was due to release a live album, but that was scrapped.  The group was Winwood, Capaldi and Wood with Rich Grech.    I really like the two live tracks.  I like the version of Glad better than the one on On The Road.  The sound quality is a little off (like there is some wow and flutter to the tape), but I think it gives the music a unique, eerie feel to it.  It really sets the type of atmosphere that you get at a great concert where the music takes you somewhere else.    The original album is one of Traffic's best.  It has different sound than the earlier Traffic albums.  It really makes good use of Winwood's soulful voice.  Later Traffic albums would be brighter and more rock oriented.    This was originally going to be a Winwood solo album and it sounds like it in parts.  With Winwood overdubbing most of the instruments, the album has a unique sound to it.  It certainly does not sound like a typical rock album.        Note that both Capaldi and Wood have died.

B00005NB0H|5.0|It is amazing that a few songs recorded live more than 30 years ago could sound so great today! The sound is raw, live, yet crystal clear. The band effortlessly transitions from hard edged, pulse pounding, hard driving rock and roll, to delicately beautiful vocal and musical harmonies and melodies, often many times within a single song. (The Who was truly unique in this regard, in their time.) Townsend is practically ripping his guitar strings to shreds at one moment, and picking out a subdued melody in the next. I believe it was Townsend who once said Keith Moon thinks of the drums as a lead instrument, and I feel there is no great capture of Moon's talent than this recording. He truly was one of the world's most gifted rock drummers, and he had a style that was all his own. He is so fast at times, it is difficult not to think that there must have been 2 drummers. <br /> <br />Turn this album up and at some points it's so overwhelming that you can barely think, your blood will be rushing, and at other times so quiet you could almost hear a pin drop. The audience was obviously spell bound by the performance. <br /> <br />I am a long time Who fan, but forget about that. Even if you've never heard The Who before, if you have any interest in rock and roll, at it's roots, at it's greatest, in it's prime, you must hear this recording. You will have a new appreciation for the talents of these musicians after really listening to this album. It is, in my opinion, simply the greatest live album of all time, by one of the great live bands of all time, at the peak of their prime. Get It.

6304765789|4.0|Directed by David Fincher, 1997's \\"The Game\\" is a very cleverly constructed and engaging thriller, although the implausibility of the whole 'game' leaves one with such a \\"give me a break\\" taste in their mouth that it simply can't be hailed as a masterpiece.    Nicholas Van Orton (Michael Douglas) is an incredibly wealthy investment banker who seems to be incredibly miserable, partly because of the daily grind of his work, and also because he's divorced and basically lives alone. His brother Conrad (Sean Penn) is seemingly aware of this, and in attempt to 'spice things up' for Nick, tells him about a suspicious company he should call named CRS, i.e. Consumer Recreation Services. Conrad tells his brother he's called them before and that they gave him a life changing experience in his own right. Nick ultimately gives in to temptation, not really knowing what he's getting into, and before he knows it, the 'game' begins.    On the positive side, the mostly dark cinematography of the movie is extremely fitting and effective, and with the construction of the script being as engagingly clever as it is, we don't get the first real inkling as to just how impossibly far-fetched it all is until about  of the way into this 2+ hour film. And the movie's 'big climax' IS suspenseful and surprising, albeit ultimately outrageous, and the final scene amusingly provides one last macabre twist.      The film is also a tour-de-force for Michael Douglas, who appears in every single scene.  It really is intriguing to watch a painstakingly maintained control freak have the proverbial rugs pulled out from under him at every turn, and Douglas is perfect for the role--intense, yet natural, and capturing the various emotions of his character masterfully.  Deborah Kara Unger's performance is also memorable--Douglas and she have an excellent on-screen chemistry.  Sean Penn, on the other hand, strikes me as being considerably miscast, but he doesn't have that much screen time anyway.    In the end, this is a better-than-average thriller. It's highly entertaining despite its extreme implausibility and the rather underwhelming & laughable ending.
0156027321|5.0|After recently having a run of bad-book luck, I decided to re-read one I knew I'd enjoy.  I loved Life of Pi the first time, and I loved it the second time as well. <br /> <br />I won't go into detail about the plot; there's plenty of reviews here that cover that.  On the surface it's about a boy stranded on a lifeboat in the Pacific ocean with a tiger...but there are multiple levels of meaning to the story.  You've probably read that the book promises to make you believe in god...well that is questionable, but it does make you believe in the power of perception and attitude.  The ending blew me away - can't say much without giving it away, but I thought about this book for weeks after finishing. <br /> <br />Life of Pi is just such a great story.  I love the characters - mainly Pi and the tiger.  This book is so well-written that it made me love a tiger.  It is one of the rare books that kept me up reading too late and I was so sad to find myself nearing the end of it.  It is a book I have bought for numerous friends and is one of the few that I will continue to re-read.  I envy anyone who hasn't yet read it because my only regret is that I can't read it again for the first time.
B00005JNJV|4.0|\\"Batman Begins\\" is one of the classier comic book adaptions of recent years. While it has far less in common with the DC comic book than one might think, virtually all the changes made to the characters and their history were essential for an audience that remembers the Tim Burton Batman films but seldom (if ever) reads a Batman comic book.  <br /> <br />This DVD is the single-disc version of the film, without most of the extras that the two-DVD set contains. Be aware of this before you order. If the extras are what you'd like, go for the two-DVD set. If not, used versions of the single-disc version are cheaply and readily available. <br /> <br />The film traces Bruce Wayne's journey from an embittered and self-destructive young man into his metamorphosis into a mysterious and powerful urban vigillante. Christian Bale throws himself into the dual roles of Bruce Wayne and Batman, giving us the best Batman since Michael Keaton. He's also given ample support from a Who's Who of Hollywood blockbusters - including Michael Caine, Liam Neeson, Rutger Hauer, Morgan Freeman, Katie Holmes, and Cillian Murphy. Along the way, there are strong echoes of the Tim Burton films, through the character designs, music, and general mood. There are also some top-notch action sequences, including one of the strangest car chases you're likely to see. <br /> <br />The film isn't entirely successful due to the almost total lack of chemistry between Bale and Holmes, and the absence of a truly gripping villain. Coming on the heels of the \\"Spiderman\\" movies, \\"Batman Begin\\" has villians whose motivations are far too shadowy to fathom. Liam Neeson turns in a fine performance as Ra's Al Ghul, and Cillian Murphy is appropriately eerie as the Scarecrow, but neither character is fleshed out enough (or over-the-top enough)to command our attention the way Jack Nicholson did as the Joker many years ago. <br /> <br />Still, this is a great start to what will hopefully be a long-running and successful series. This is a movie well worth watching again.
B0000AQS0F|5.0|Back in 2002, Firefly was the promising new sci-fi show on Fox cursed with such a horrible string of bad executive decisions, it's a miracle how it managed to gain a dedicated following. The network insisted on various changes to the show; they aired episodes in a different order than its creators intended; they even cropped the picture to a 4:3 aspect ratio for TV, although it was meant to be shown in widescreen. No wonder it eventually got canceled halfway through the season with three more episodes made but never aired.  <br /> <br />All this, I've only learned recently, as with 2005 came the release of Serenity, the motion picture, which has lead a whole new bunch of us to discover this interesting world. Having seen the movie, I was aching for more. As luck would have it, this time there actually was more: this very DVD set, Firefly - The Complete Series.  <br /> <br />I'm happy to say that it has exceeded my expectations in every way. On its own, the untimely cancellation of the show make Firefly hard to recommend without any reservations. Couple it with Serenity, however, and they make a thoroughly excellent package together. With Firefly, you get 675 more minutes of the same great cast of characters and many more of their interesting adventures, although each understandably somewhat less grandiose than that of the movie.  <br /> <br />Even the bonus features are impeccable. Of the 14 episodes, exactly half of them got a commentary track, each with a different set of people. Four of the cast are featured at least one once: Nathan Fillion, Alan Tudyk, Jewel Staite and Morena Baccarin. And of course, Joss Whedon, the brains behind the project, is along in three of them to share his thoughts. Beyond that, there's a gag reel, deleted scenes, behind the scenes features, and more.  <br /> <br />Really, the fact that this was released on 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment, the same studio which so mistreated the show on TV, is no cause for concern. This DVD set does Firefly justice and treats it with the respect it always deserved.  <br /> <br />The bottom line is, you'll want to pick up both this and the Serenity DVD. That the two are unlikely to ever get officially bundled together is only because they were produced by different studios.
