Fans of the original will notice a few nice cameos but will probably hate this film.  If you love films just for the effects, then this is one of the best flicks you can ever watch.
0060765496|5.0|One of the miracles of C.S. Lewis is that he is able to incorporate a sense of the mystical and magical with the form of the world in a Christian framework without either aspect becoming forced or stilted. The stories that Lewis has crafted in the Chronicles of Narnia stand on their own as good storytelling even without the underpinning of Christian imagery - they are strong tales, kin in many ways to the Lord of the Rings cycle, which makes sense, given the friendship and professional relationship of Lewis with Tolkein.<br /><br />This particular text, 'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe', is the second installment in the overall Narnia series, but each story is able to stand on its own. This is a story that almost begins with 'once upon a time...' It is a good story for children of all ages (including 40-year-old children like me). The story begins in the dark days of the London blitz, with the children being sent away for their protection. This was common for people in all social classes, from the royal family on down, to send the children out to the countryside for the duration of the war - when Lewis was writing and publishing the Narnia books, this experience would have been fresh in the minds of the readers. Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy are the family children sent to stay with old Professor and his less-than-amiable housekeeper; it comes as no surprise that the children hope to escape from this as much as from the bombs in London, and escape they did.<br /><br />Lucy found it first - the portal to Narnia, in the back of the wardrobe in the special room. Then Edmund (though he would lie about it), and then all four make the journey into Narnia, where they discover themselves to be the likely heirs of a prophetic chain of events freeing the land from the evil of the wintery White Witch, who was then styling herself as the Queen of Narnia. In fact, the real king of Narnia was Aslan, a majestic lion full of power and grace, whose soul was as pure as any child's hope for the future.<br /><br />The Christian images would seem familiar to any liturgical churchgoer, but the there are also other symbols that fit beyond the religious that tap into deeper longings - evil here is not a hot place, but a frozen place, where the emotions are cold and sharp. The lesser creatures are the virtuous ones, and the children lead the way to the redemption of all. The battle of good and evil takes place in epic form, fitting many forms of heroic tales. The lion Aslan stands for the Christ figure, but can also conjure images of the lion of England - Peter's shield with a red lion makes him both the stand-in for the first of the apostles as well as a perfect casting for St. George. Other parallels abound.<br /><br />The children themselves live a good life in Narnia, but eventually return to their English countryside encampment, with spirits and hopefulness renewed.<br /><br />This is a tale of extraordinary power, and one that stays with the reader for a long time. Long before Harry Potter, there was Narnia - a tale that is not only fun and riveting, but also one with a strong moral lens that includes not only power, but the giving up of power; not only victory, but also forgiveness and sacrifice. Revenge is an emotion that is defeated here, and good triumphs at the last.<br /><br />A grand story, and a great film!child's hope for the future.  <br /> <br />The Christian images would seem familiar to any liturgical churchgoer, but the there are also other symbols that fit beyond the religious that tap into deeper longings - evil here is not a hot place, but a frozen place, where the emotions are cold and sharp. The lesser creatures are the virtuous ones, and the children lead the way to the redemption of all. The battle of good and evil takes place in epic form, fitting many forms of heroic tales. The lion Aslan stands for the Christ figure, but can also conjure images of the lion of England - Peter's shield with a red lion makes him both the stand-in for the first of the apostles as well as a perfect casting for St. George. Other parallels abound.  <br /> <br />The children themselves live a good life in Narnia, but eventually return to their English countryside encampment, with spirits and hopefulness renewed.  <br /> <br />This is a tale of extraordinary power, and one that stays with the reader for a long time. Long before Harry Potter, there was Narnia - a tale that is not only fun and riveting, but also one with a strong moral lens that includes not only power, but the giving up of power; not only victory, but also forgiveness and sacrifice. Revenge is an emotion that is defeated here, and good triumphs at the last.  <br /> <br />A grand story, and a great film! <br />
B00005JO1Y|4.0|\\"King Kong\\" is a good film.  It's one of the better movies to come out in the past year.  It is full of action, romance, and comedy.  It has a solid cast and a nice musical score.  The special effects are very good and the writing keeps the bulk of the story moving at a rather swift pace.<br /><br />With all of that said, I have to admit that there were a few things that I didn't really like.  The beginning of the film, including the introduction of the primary players and the trip to Skull Island, definitely would have benefited from a little more editing.  It's just too long.  Once the crew reaches Skull Island, however, the story picks up to a very nice pace with a couple of comedic and loving interludes between Kong and Ann Darrow to break the pace a bit.  The action is scattered amongst charging brachiosaurs, giant insects and natives.  The stampede scene does seem a bit overdone, but it is very fun to watch.  The battle between Kong and the T-Rexes also seems to suffer a bit from overkill, but it's put together so well that it's enjoyable to watch on the screen.<br /><br />Naomi Watts, Jack Black, and Adrien Brody are all good in this film, but let's face it, Kong is the star.  The CGI gorilla with a big heart is quite impressive on the screen, and his emotions flow smoothly and quickly from anger to hate to sadness and even fear.<br /><br />The outcome of this story is obvious.  Jackson pulls out no magic tricks for the big guy when he climbs that Empire State Building.  The ending is rather moving, but Black's Denham character sort of weakens it.<br /><br />In short, this is a very good action/adventure/romance in the old cliffhanger vein of the 30's and 40's.  It's also very obvious that Peter Jackson loved this film very much and put a lot into its development.  However, much like George Lucas went a little overboard with special effects in Episodes I, II, and III, I think that Jackson is guilty of the same thing here.<br /><br />I should state that the PG-13 rating is primarily for some rather gruesome death scenes on Skull Island.  There is a little language, but watching men get sucked to death by leach-like creatures may not sit well with younger viewers.<br /><br />Recommended to fans of popcorn adventure and, of course, Peter Jackson.  Just don't expect a tale as wonderful as the \\"Lord of the Rings\\" trilogy.  This film is sufficient, but don't let people carry you away with talk of awards.  This film may get a nod for music or even special effects, but none of the actors have enough to work with here to gain an Oscar.  Just know that if you like gorillas tearing up the jungle and a sizeable chunk of New York, you'll enjoy this film.te that the PG-13 rating is primarily for some rather gruesome death scenes on Skull Island.  There is a little language, but watching men get sucked to death by leach-like creatures may not sit well with younger viewers. <br /> <br />Recommended to fans of popcorn adventure and, of course, Peter Jackson.  Just don't expect a tale as wonderful as the \\"Lord of the Rings\\" trilogy.  This film is sufficient, but don't let people carry you away with talk of awards.  This film may get a nod for music or even special effects, but none of the actors have enough to work with here to gain an Oscar.  Just know that if you like gorillas tearing up the jungle and a sizeable chunk of New York, you'll enjoy this film.
B000B8QEZG|5.0|Madonna is riding high (thankfully not on horseback), and the well-executed electronica/dance formula of her new album, \\"Confessions on a Dance Floor\\" is indeed the culprit. Although her ambitious yet ultimately underwhelming 2003 disc \\"American Life\\" fizzled away soon after its release, it hardly forecasted her demise, for \\"Confessions\\" is a far more sturdy collection.<br /><br />Taking off with \\"Hung Up,\\" the Material Girl's 36th top-10 single, it is evident from the get-go that this album relies less on introspection than on sing-a-long choruses and frothy dance beats. Longer than its radio version, the track sounds even better stretched out to a majestic six minutes, until it blends into the hypnotic \\"Get Together\\" after a ticking alarm clock suddenly blasts. The pulsating track, which can best be described as an electronic freeze-out, will rub listeners in all the right places with its spare yet sexy lyrics and mercurial pace.<br /><br />The aptly titled \\"Let It Will Be\\" is a scintillating affair that takes the listener on an abbreviated ride on the roller coaster of Madonna's history, while maintaining the credo of its namesake. \\"Jump\\" and \\"How High?\\" follow the same self-effacement but delve deeper - beckoning listeners to make judgment calls about their own lives while still remaining personal. The former, which benefits from smoldering dance beats and a solid melody, belongs on the radio.<br /><br />Elsewhere, the vocoder-stuffed \\"Forbidden Love\\" is a slow-burning '80s throwback, while the pulsing synths of \\"Future Lovers\\" recall Donna Summer's disco classic \\"I Feel Love.\\" While delightfully retro, both songs are adventurous enough to suggest a futuristic sound. Fashioned similarly is \\"Sorry,\\" a tribute to those who simply cannot forgive.<br /><br />Other tracks include \\"Like It Or Not,\\" a blunt ode to self-sustenance, the tongue-twisting \\"Push\\" and \\"Isaac,\\" which reflects the diva's notorious interest in Kabbalah and contains Middle-Eastern chanting.<br /><br />The sole misstep on the collection is \\"I Love New York,\\" which has embarrassing lyrics and a choppy melody.<br /><br />Overall, \\"Confessions\\" is an infectious, high quality pop album that serves as yet another testament to Madonna's longevity. While it may not be as formidable as \\"Ray of Light\\" or \\"Like a Prayer,\\" it is a genuine gem.<br /><br />A deluxe edition includes an extra track, \\"Fighting Spirit,\\" a 40-page picture book, an 80-page journal book that includes some of Madonna's diary entries, and a one-month subscription to ICON, her fanclub.<br /><br />Last but not least, iTunes offers three different variations of the album, as well as assortment of club mixes of \\"Hung Up.\\"g. <br /> <br />The sole misstep on the collection is \\"I Love New York,\\" which has embarrassing lyrics and a choppy melody. <br /> <br />Overall, \\"Confessions\\" is an infectious, high quality pop album that serves as yet another testament to Madonna's longevity. While it may not be as formidable as \\"Ray of Light\\" or \\"Like a Prayer,\\" it is a genuine gem. <br /> <br />A deluxe edition includes an extra track, \\"Fighting Spirit,\\" a 40-page picture book, an 80-page journal book that includes some of Madonna's diary entries, and a one-month subscription to ICON, her fanclub. <br /> <br />Last but not least, iTunes offers three different variations of the album, as well as assortment of club mixes of \\"Hung Up.\\"

B000BBOUU4|4.0|I loved this movie as a child.  It had a magical aura about it, with all of the crazy creations in the factory and the eccentric and fascinating Mr. Wonka. <br /> <br />This version is a good modern-day representation of the movie.  The sets are outstanding and creatively done.  The Oompa Loompas are slightly more disturbing in this version (which may have something to do with the fact that they're all played by a single actor), but they're entertaining.  There is a slight twist in plot in this version, as you get to delve a bit more deeply into Willy Wonka's childhood, but I feel it works within the story. <br /> <br />This movie certainly has the Tim Burton stamp on it.  Even if you didn't know he was the director, you would be able to draw similarities between the feel of this movie and his others such as Edward Scissorhands.  It's worth a watch.

B000E97Y6K|5.0|(from an earlier feature, copyright 2005 Michael F. Hopkins)<br /><br />If anyone thought that director Peter Jackson would<br />rest on the laurels of his grand success in adapting<br />Tolkien's LORD OF THE RINGS into three of the finest<br />movies ever made, this film will make them stop and<br />wonder anew. Jackson's long-awaited upgrade of KING<br />KONG is a superb motion picture, balancing wit and<br />tragedy, satire and sentiment, delivered with<br />rippling power and a passionate depth which will<br />not be ignored.<br />Bypassing the camped-up travesty from Lorenzo Semple<br />Jr. and Dino DeLaurentiis which stunk up the late<br />1970s, the Oscar winning scriptwriting team of Jackson,<br />Fran Walsh and Phillipa Boyens grow their story from<br />the original 1930s RKO classic; paying persistent<br />homage and respect, while filling out the story<br />even further. Where the original KONG was a product<br />of the Depression era, Jackson's KONG provides a<br />sharp perspective of those turbulent times, and<br />what such sheer desperation could drive one to<br />do.<br /><br />Those who complain about the film's 3 hour plus<br />length, particularly those who bemoan the film's<br />first hour need to watch the film, not their<br />stopwatches. Jackson's sense of pacing, so crucial<br />to deliver the lengthy RING cycle, serves him<br />well once more. KONG's pacing is brisk and fluid,<br />at times cutting as a pitchman's jive, at other<br />times as gentle as a precious moment quietly<br />shared. In a word, it smokes.<br />Further, the first hour is the all-crucial intro<br />of characters and motivations, which is a particular<br />point where Jackson, cast, and crew nurture the<br />original tale of thrill-seeking showmanship into<br />a saga of clueless adventurers running headlong<br />into their own worst nightmares.<br /><br />Jackson, Walsh, and Boyens bring this particular<br />point home with their broader look into the key<br />individuals of the steamship's crew. Instead of<br />one-spot bodies to be dumped over the cliff, we<br />are given a diverse array of characters which the<br />audience has a deeper stake in, whatever happens.<br />Even when the tale dangles the poignant thread<br />of Joseph Conrad's \\"Heart Of Darkness\\" as a<br />gaze into the myriad motivations at hand, we<br />have at least one spot which revels in an equally<br />unholy obsession borne straight from Herman<br />Melville's \\"Moby Dick\\".... or Clint Eastwood's<br />\\"White Hunter, Black Heart.\\"<br />While Thomas Kretschmann's Captain Engelhorn<br />paints a tougher, more wary seafarer than the crusty<br />depiction in the original film, the one to watch<br />most vividly is First Mate Hayes, a wise and<br />world-weathered sailor beautifully delivered<br />by Evan Parke. Of all on the ship, it is Parke's<br />character who knows exactly what's in store<br />for most of them, and warns young Jimmy<br />(a Jack London-like wayfarer brought home by<br />the fine talent of Jamie Bell) that what's coming<br />is no adventure full of derring-do, fortune and<br />glory to be had by all. Time and tragic trespass<br />prove the fatal accuracy of Hayes' words.<br /><br />Speaking of that very trespass, Jackson's wry depiction<br />of endangered indigenous people reacting to outside<br />intrusion vs. the pitiful minstrelsy of grass-skirted<br />\\"natives\\" selling doo-dah stereotypes on \\"The Great<br />White Way\\" is an ingenious set of scenes in themselves.<br />Between this and the weather-beaten compassion of Parke's<br />performance, Jackson, cast and crew directly address<br />the one great flaw in the original KING KONG, and<br />masterfully turns it around.<br /><br />However one may have expected the LORD OF THE RINGS<br />composer Howard Shore to provide the music here, the<br />ever-conceptual James Newton Howard delivers a<br />masterwork of a score. Able to turn motifs on a dime,<br />and keep the balance of the greater drama(s) at hand<br />at all times, this KING KONG score is one of the<br />all-time classics.<br />Already acclaimed for his epic scores for the penetrating<br />films of M. Night Shyamalan, and other standouts (such as<br />his rippling 2003 score for P. J. Hogan's definitive take<br />on PETER PAN), Howard is justly recognized as one of the<br />most multitalented of all film scorists. His occasional<br />quote of a Max Steiner passage from the original KONG's<br />legendary score is a dutiful riot! All in all, Howard<br />delivers quite an inspirational feat of composition,<br />all around.<br /><br />Alan Lee's design work, once more, is sheer magic. At<br />points, some of the Skull Island overviews touch upon<br />Frank Frazetta's legendary vistas, capped with Lee's<br />own touch of the substantially fantastic.<br />No faerie lands here, the ethereal eye of the highly-<br />acclaimed illustrator captures the dangerous allure of<br />the prehistoric jungle, rife with dinosaurs and assorted<br />crawling ghastlies which recall Jackson's earlier work<br />in the Horror field. With each peril, however, Lee,<br />Jackson and the remarkable team at WETA imparts the<br />presence of an unknown world; an unknown which is<br />needlessly disturbed in the name of Western financial<br />pursuit.<br />Just as aptly, the traps and hypocrisies of the Western<br />jungle are depicted with stunning detail. Hearing Al<br />Jolson sing about good times and lots of money, while<br />the film's opening unveils scene after scene of crippling<br />want, is as sharp a reflection of the tale's timeless<br />duality as one can get; a particularly special summation<br />of the times that this tale comes from.<br /><br />In this, Kyle Chandler, Adrien Brody and Jack Black<br />unveil a brilliant comment of the differing faces of show<br />biz, then and now. Brody plays a creative auteur entrapped<br />amidst corporate confinement and exploitation, while<br />Black captures the chummy-sounding personification of<br />okeydoke on the make, and Chandler portrays a Grade-B<br />leading-man hopelessly full of himself.<br />For all the bluster of Black's Carl Denham, or the<br />preening of Chandler's Bruce Baxter (a comment on the<br />original KONG's Bruce Cabot?), it is the quiet wisdom<br />of Brody's Jack Driscoll which rises to the occasion,<br />meeting each new danger with great courage. Needing to<br />come to grips with his own words, Driscoll will dare to<br />cross lethal terrain, and stand at the top of the<br />world to secure the well-being of one special woman.<br /><br />Let's talk about that woman. Naomi Watts is just<br />plain wonderful. To Ann Darrow, she brings the air<br />of naivete, gusto, wit and wide-eyed innocence which<br />marked Fay Wray's original portrayal of the role.<br />With this, Watts adds an astonishing depth in<br />projecting the despair of virtue besieged by the<br />despairing times of The \\"Great\\" Depression. Too,<br />with her uncanny ability to gain Kong's respect,<br />Watts certainly brings new meaning to the term<br />\\"Broadway trouper\\"! Small wonder that Ms. Wray,<br />just before she passed on in 2004, gave Ms. Watts her<br />personal blessing. A signature performance.<br /><br />Which brings us to the standout work of Andy Serkis.<br />If you think his body language was superb portraying<br />Gollum in THE LORD OF THE RINGS, wait until you see<br />his bravura performance delivering the unspoken<br />drives of the Great Ape. WETA's digital imagery does<br />the original's SFX wizard, Willis O'Brien, great honor<br />with their wondrous genius, but it is Serkis' gifted<br />physicality which brings the majesty and tragedy<br />of KING KONG so achingly home.<br />In turn, it is between Serkis' Chaplin-worthy pantomime,<br />and Watts' grasp upon the loneliness lurking beneath the<br />terror, that the saga's crucial bond takes firm hold here.<br />What ensues with Kong and Ann is not a lust misplaced by<br />menace, but the camaraderie of two lost souls; each facing<br />the abyss, shorn of illusions for a brighter future. What<br />comes from that bond is what makes this KING KONG so very,<br />very special.<br /><br />Now we wait for Jackson and friends to deliver THE HOBBIT!<br />Meanwhile, an image I will carry in my mind and soul, for<br />years to come, is that view from the Empire State Building;<br />looking into the vast, unknown horizon, for one loving<br />moment, without grief or fear...nding personification of<br />okeydoke on the make, and Chandler portrays a Grade-B<br />leading-man hopelessly full of himself.<br />For all the bluster of Black's Carl Denham, or the<br />preening of Chandler's Bruce Baxter (a comment on the<br />original KONG's Bruce Cabot?), it is the quiet wisdom<br />of Brody's Jack Driscoll which rises to the occasion,<br />meeting each new danger with great courage. Needing to<br />come to grips with his own words, Driscoll will dare to<br />cross lethal terrain, and stand at the top of the<br />world to secure the well-being of one special woman.<br /><br />Let's talk about that woman. Naomi Watts is just<br />plain wonderful. To Ann Darrow, she brings the air<br />of naivete, gusto, wit and wide-eyed innocence which<br />marked Fay Wray's original portrayal of the role.<br />With this, Watts adds an astonishing depth in<br />projecting the despair of virtue besieged by the<br />despairing times of The \\"Great\\" Depression. Too,<br />with her uncanny ability to gain Kong's respect,<br />Watts certainly brings new meaning to the term<br />\\"Broadway trouper\\"! Small wonder that Ms. Wray,<br />just before she passed on in 2004, gave Ms. Watts her<br />personal blessing. A signature performance.<br /><br />Which brings us to the standout work of Andy Serkis.<br />If you think his body language was superb portraying<br />Gollum in THE LORD OF THE RINGS, wait until you see<br />his bravura performance delivering the unspoken<br />drives of the Great Ape. WETA's digital imagery does<br />the original's SFX wizard, Willis O'Brien, great honor<br />with their wondrous genius, but it is Serkis' gifted<br />physicality which brings the majesty and tragedy<br />of KING KONG so achingly home.<br />In turn, it is between Serkis' Chaplin-worthy pantomime,<br />and Watts' grasp upon the loneliness lurking beneath the<br />terror, that the saga's crucial bond takes firm hold here.<br />What ensues with Kong and Ann is not a lust misplaced by<br />menace, but the camaraderie of two lost souls; each facing<br />the abyss, shorn of illusions for a brighter future. What<br />comes from that bond is what makes this KING KONG so very,<br />very special.<br /><br />Now we wait for Jackson and friends to deliver THE HOBBIT!<br />Meanwhile, an image I will carry in my mind and soul, for<br />years to come, is that view from the Empire State Building;<br />looking into the vast, unknown horizon, for one loving<br />moment, without grief or fear...
B000058983|5.0|I'll make this as short as I can: <br />Forever Changes is unique, it's perfect, and it's essential. <br />Arthur Lee does not have the best voice in the world, nor are the rest of the musicians masters of their art. B00004SAAX|5.0|It is hard to express in words what an incredible achievement this is.  The immense feats of memory alone, demanding far greater efforts than sighted performers face, command our respect.  So does the consistent quality of Walcha's playing.<br /><br />Bach's almost mathematical absorbtion with fugue lies at the centre of his genius.  He was an organist first and foremost, an organist all his life.  Like Bach, Walcha is an obsessive controller who uses music to shape his world.  He treats each piece as a treasure to be cherished and burnished, and this makes him the greatest Bach organist since Schweitzer.  We are told that Bach would travel miles to hear great organists perform, and Helmut Walcha is just such an organist as those.<br /><br />The magnificent instrument used here is celestial in tone.  To those for whom Bach fugues conjure up images of Christopher Lee playing Dracula, or dull Sundays in church, here is one of the great achievements of Western civilization, a glittering pinnacle of Baroque art, performed by a great modern spirit, in one handy box.  You can't have Michaelangelo ceilings in your home, or Bernini bronzes in your living room, but by golly, you can put this on your stereo.

0060825219|4.0|I've returned once again to one of my favorite authors to review his latest work. Paulo Coelho of international fame for The Alchemist, 11 Minutes and The Devil and Miss Prym, has released his latest The Zahir. According to the book, the Zahir in Arabic means present, visible, incapable of being unnoticed. It is something that grabs our thought, mind and spirit and demands our full attention. It is believed to lead to either Holiness or madness.  In this book, the Zahir is a woman, an idea of a woman, a longing. Our main character sounds very familiar to our author; in fact our hero is a famous author now living in Paris, with his books being published in nearly every language. (which sounds like Mr. Coelho. This book is being published in 50 countries/languages this year alone. [...]) The author writes books that millions love, adore, and claim changes their lives. Yet he appears to have stopped living the type of deliberate life he writes about. He has settled into a complacent life.<br /> Then one day his wife disappears. Over time she becomes his Zahir; he writes a book about love and for a while the Zahir fades. Then he meets the man he believes she had left with and the Zahir returns.<br /> This is a wonderful story about becoming, and remembering who you were meant to be, not who you settled into. It will stir in you a passion to be more than you think you can be, and, to give more, and love more purely. Follow a man who goes in search of an estranged wife, only to find himself.
0440236304|5.0|This is the first book in a set of 4 books by the author, the books start with his training as a paratrooper in WWII, and follow his time in the war until he gets discharged after the war. The books in chronological order are 1)Currahee! 2) The Road to Arnhem 3) Seven Roads to Hell 4) Beyond the Rhime. By all means, read every one of them.<br /><br />For those who call WWII, the last \\"good war\\", this is a wake up. This war was just as full of horror and nightmare as any conflict, and the men treated as poorly. We get a view of the daily misery of the troops between the episodes of their bravery driven by the urge to kill or be killed. The author was a member of the newly formed Screaming Eagles 101st Airborne Division, and they made history and a reputation in this war.<br /><br />In this first book, Burgett takes us to his training as a 19 year old Paratrooper in 1944, and then on to England. The newly formed division gets the supreme test as paratoopers. Paratroops or Airbonre units are dropped behind enemy lines to shock the enemy, draw the enemy to them, diverting resources from the main line of attack so infantry and mechanized untis can move in. This may include seizing a key road or river crossing until the main units arrive. It is incredibly tough for them as they are often outmanned, outsupplied, and outgunned, facing tanks and artillery with nothing more than their own rifles, bazookas, and mortars they can fly in with. They are expected to do this for 1 to 2 days before relief arrives. But in Normandy, they were kept in action for seven harrowing days.<br /><br />This book series by Donald Burgett is the most graphic and honest description of being an active fighting soldier in WWII I have read and left a deep impression on me. Simple words and detailed memeories from a simple man. It is a great read, and I could not put it down.
B00005JOFO|5.0|Brokeback Mountain is a film of epic proportions! All involved in this project should be extremely proud of themselves. The film is an Ansel Adams photo come to life, yet with an emotional center that no previous \\"gay\\" film has ever had.  <br /> <br />Too many films have been made about young men coming out of the closet. There's almost a cookie cutter mold for creating these films. Maybe that's part of the reason that this film is so fantastic...it's not about coming out. It's about the far more realistic - not hiding, but simply controlling your feeling, burying your love and remaining \\"in\\" the closet. Good or bad, that is what many gay men force themselves to do. Is it bad? That's not for anyone but those men involved to determine. Is it detrimental to them and their lives? Again... <br /> <br />For Jack and Ennis (gyllenhaal and ledger), as cowboys in the early 60's all the way through the early 80's, coming out of the closet or even hiding in full view is just not an option. It \\"doesn't play\\" you could say.  <br /> <br />Oh, Jack is willing to take the chance - he's the risk taker of the two, but Ennis...no. Ennis knows what awaits them if they dare openly face their \\"dark\\" side. <br /> <br />So instead, for over twenty years, these two \\"straight\\" cowboys, each with a family of his own, meet clandestinely at the \\"scene of the crime\\" - at Brokeback Mountain for a week or so a couple times a year and they maintain their passionate love affair. <br /> <br />Are they gay? Are they straight? Are they hiding? Do they really love each other? I'm not going to tell you. That would be spoiling the film for you. <br /> <br />Suffice it to say, that no major studio, no major director, no major actors have ever tackled a film of this stature or magnitude. Oh, don't give me the crap about \\"Philadelphia\\". It was a cop out. Hanks and Banderas never kissed. They never related to each other. No, this film is the one that will forever be seen as the film that broke all the stereotypes that went before. It is the film that will be referred to in film history books as the one that broke down the walls. <br /> <br />Every actor in this film is firing on every cylinder. Ledger, who up until now, I thought was a light weight pretty boy, delivers a tour de force performance. He's the quiet, yet very much NOT the introspective man. He just doesn't have much to say. He swallows his words but you can see every thought as it rolls across his face. Ledger should have the best actor performance nailed. Gyllenhaal, too, delivers a performance of amazing depth and emotional range. His anger...his desperation... his loss... towards the end of the film, is palpable. Michelle Williams (Ledger's actual wife) as Ennis' wife cannot possibly be the same actress who played Jen on Dawson's Creek. No way. This actress is masterful and mature and you certainly can feel her pain. Her face tells the whole story. Randy Quaid and Anne Hathaway also deliver absolutely phenomenal performances. This is a vehicle for some of the best performances you'll ever see on film - ever! <br /> <br />This is the film that lets the world know that even the most masculine of men can find deep within themselves an aching need that, no matter how hard they try, cannot be suppressed by playing it straight. These two men tried against all efforts to fit the mold society set for them. But as Jack says, \\"I guess ol' Brokeback really got us good.\\" They are bound to each other. <br /> <br />Does it have flaws? Yes. It's overly long. Twenty minutes could have been shaved off. However, with this film I'm beginning to realize why all of Ang Lee's films seem to drag on too long. He wants to take us along the road with each of his characters to the most complete of jumping off points. He wants us to fully understand them. Is it always effective? No. However, he is the director. And his past efforts are certainly example enough of how masterful this director is. I'll grant him his extra time so long as he continues to show us the true emotional center of characters, instead of relegating an entire character's reason for being to a single line of dialogue as many American films do. Lee's films are much more realistic and allow the audience to truly connect with the characters. <br /> <br />I'll be buying this film for certain. It warrants watching over and over (if nothing more than for figuring out what the heck some of the characters are saying from time to time). <br /> <br />Simply awesome!
B00000APLB|3.0|The Rolling Stones' \\"live\\" records have never been particularly outstanding.  Many point to GET YOUR YA-YA'S OUT and it is the best the Stones have ever done.  However, several other bands had overshadowed GET YOUR YA-YA'S OUT as \\"live\\" albums go in the early 1970's.  THE WHO LIVE AT LEEDS and THE ALLMAN BROTHERS AT THE FILLMORE EAST come to mind as prime examples.  Even Cream's WHEELS OF FIRE released two years before kicked the \\"live\\" Stones' butt.<br /><br />All that having been said, GET YOUR YA-YA'S OUT is still the standard against which all other Stones' \\"live\\" records are measured.  Unfortunately, GET YOUR YA-YAS OUT has a spark and fire that LOVE YOU LIVE does not.  For most of the record, the Stones sound tired and sluggish.  By the time you get to the end of the first disc, you don't have high expectations for the second disc.<br /><br />Nevertheless, things do make an interesting turn with the Stones doing a small set at the El Mocambo.  Well, almost.  You would think the Stones doing a blues set in the small confines of a clubhouse would be like shooting fish in a barrel; but you would be wrong.  \\"Mannish Boy\\", \\"Crackin' Up\\" and \\"Little Red Rooster\\" all sound underpowered and unimaginative -and doubts finally set in that the Stones may be all washed up.<br /><br />That is until \\"Around and Around\\".  Chuck Berry chords must kick some adrenaline into Keith Richards' veins because this is where LOVE YOU LIVE takes a quantum leap into the energy of a stampede of wild horses.  This song and all that follows is everything you could hope for in a \\"live\\" Stones' record.  Of course, choosing \\"It's Only Rock 'N Roll\\", \\"Brown Sugar\\", \\"Jumpin' Jack Flash\\" and \\"Sympathy For The Devil\\" to close the album is almost guaranteed to make a believer out of anyone.<br /><br />So where does this leave us?  Three quarters of a double disc set is uninspired while the last five songs lift the Stones on Olympian heights.  Well, I'm glad I have this album.  Granted, I skip the dross and go right for the gold every time.  Occasionally I give the rest a listen to see if I've missed something; but it all adds up the same.  So if you're a true Stones fan, get it and know what you're getting.  If you are new to this \\"Greatest Rock and Roll Band in the World\\" stuff, pass this up for the real classic albums:<br /><br />1.) BEGGARS BANQUET<br /><br />2.) LET IT BLEED<br /><br />3.) STICKY FINGERS<br /><br />4.) EXILES ON MAIN STREET and (perhaps)<br /><br />5.) IT'S ONLY ROCK AND ROLL<br /><br />Build your Stones collection around these albums and you'll be the better for it.kip the dross and go right for the gold every time.  Occasionally I give the rest a listen to see if I've missed something; but it all adds up the same.  So if you're a true Stones fan, get it and know what you're getting. 0743442539|5.0|John le Carre gives us a serious and gritty cold war era spy novel with \\"The Spy Who Came in From the Cold\\".  The main character is an agent  in Berlin who is recalled to London after his last contact is killed at the Berlin Wall. What follows is a spy plot that follows the main character through the depths of humanity and intrigue. This novel is so well written that you feel the emotions, paranoia, depression and anxiety  of cold war Europe in the 1960s. This is no James Bond novel: no sexy heroine, no fancy casinos and hotels, no witty phrases, no implied sex on a sunny beach. This novel is a hard core look at the spy business that pulls no punches and spares none of the innocent. This truely is the best spy novel ever written.

B000BJS4SU|4.0|While this album is not original, no blues artist is really. The blues have always been a carbon copy of African Spirituals mixed with rudimentary instrumentalism. The blues genre does not have a large variety of sound or structure. It is, arguably, one of the most simple and formative styles of music, which does not leave a whole lot of room for artistic derision, except in the intricacy of a solo or refrain. The difference of style comes in the difference in guitar sound, the choice of notes. <br /> <br />What John Mayer is doing, is applying his blues knowledge and talent to his already established pop success. People love his pop lyrics and style, and most are unaware of his talent in playing the blues. What he is attempting with this album is to combine both capacities to keep the old pop audience and drag in a new audience of blues fans. It is an attempt to resurrect or conjure new blues fans in a new, popular form.  <br /> <br />Is it successful? Well, it's still a new experiment, but it's a good start.

0792843584|5.0|I was fortunate enough to see the complete version during its one week run at Cinema I in NYC in November 1980.  Running the same length but substantially revised and improved by Cimino for the VHS/CED/Laser versions released in the mid 1980s (and now on DVD)this is probably the version Cimino would have liked to have opened in November 1980.  It's what I would call a flawed masterpiece; a one of kind film made by a director reaching beyond his grasp.  The result is  pure picture making.  To those who say it is too long, or confusing; they should pay a bit more attention.  I've seen the film over 20 times and it becomes a richer experience each time I watch it.  There are no lose ends or editing problems; the issue being style.  As one reviewer wrote in 1980, Cimino chose the lyrical over the narrative.  By the way, the Sunday performance during which I saw it, Vilmos Zsigmond driving up from Phily where he was shooting Blow Out, also attended with his crew.  Once the film was over I heard applause from his section of the theatre.  Gene Siskel was also at that performance having flown in from Chicago to review the film.  As I left the theatre, glancing over I saw him busily jotting down notes.  I guess he was too busy filling out his score card to watch what had been up on that screen.  No applause from him.<br /><br />--Joseph Egan--

B00000DHZJ|2.0|The selection is weighted towards his earlier Jimi Hendrix Experience pieces and when possible, shorter versions of the songs are given.  There is a good sampling of those here, but the sound quality is overall very flat. And I still remember how depressed I felt when the last original strip was published at the end of 1995. <br /> <br />What makes Calvin & Hobbes so great is that it is so consistently laugh-out-loud funny.  Every page of these books gets a laugh out of me.  You look at most of the comics in the newspaper and you just can't say the same about them--at best you might get a chuckle, but you never laugh out loud. <br /> <br />The quality of this collection is actually better than what I expected after reading the other reviews here.  I'm quite happy with it.  I like the \\"scrapbook\\" appearance of the pages--they look like someone has cut out the strips from the paper and glued them onto the page.  It's a nice optical illusion, and I keep touching the pages expecting a change in the texture of the paper, but it's only an illusion. <br /> <br />In a phrase, I love it, and anyone who was a fan of Calvin & Hobbes will love this too.

B00005JLF5|4.0|The many gritty, involving science fiction dramas that have cropped up in recent years- shows like the new Battlestar Galactica, Firefly, the various Stargate entries, etc., etc, probably owe a lot to Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, one of the first of the edgy SF programs of the modern era.  As such, there is much to appreciate here.  Just be aware that DS9 (especially the first couple of seasons) may seem a little tame and sedate compared to the many similarly-toned series that followed in its footsteps.<br /><br />Also, just looking at DS9 as a Star Trek show, the usual caveat applies: as the characters haven't been fully fleshed out in the initial episodes, there is a tendency on the part of the writers to trot out those oft-used Trek plot devices to keep things moving until more character-driven plots could kick in.  So, in this inital set, you have to sit through a few too many of those somewhat tedious \\"crisis of the week\\" or \\"disaster of the week\\" types of stories between the handful of really good episodes.  Of course, once the Dominion War (a DS9 \\"crisis\\" that wasn't tedious at all) takes center stage during later seasons, then long stretches of the show surpass so much that has been on TV before or since.<br /><br />So, my recommendation is to enjoy this perfectly okay first season with its only occasional glimmers of greatness, while reminding yourself that your patience will be rewarded with the really good stuff in later episodes.  Finally, the DVD extras in this Star Trek set are generous, well organized, and interesting.
B00006LLNU|4.0|i feel kind of bad writing this review and only giving it four stars, because i haven't fully digested any of the songs past number three. I have listened to the whole CD a couple times, but none of the songs except those three have really stuck in my head and all that. All the songs on here are great and are defidently worth memorizing, but i personally havent yet. But i felt compelled to give this review anyway. <br /> <br />I first heard of this band on a commercial for a CD of theirs on MTV2 a couple years ago. It was probably this CD, but i have no way of knowing without seeing the commercial again. This band is truly one of a kind. They can summon these huge instrumental symphonies with just guitars, keys, bass, drums, vocals, and various other sounds that pop up at the right time. The songs have a central melody in all of them that all other intruments and aspects are at the mercy of, and it gives it a very neat quality. The music is very serene and is the musical interpretation of looking out a window and seeing a gentle yet huge snowstorm happening before your eyes as you look out at a forest-type landscape. It is truly captivating, and very moving. Every melody on this is completely stellar, and by stellar i mean amazing, 10/10. The vocal melodies are great, the guitar melodies are great, the piano melodies are great. The singer is very Thom Yorke inspired, as he sounds a lot like him at at times, but i don't look at the guy from Sigur Ros as a rip off as he has his own thing about him. The central guitar melody that drives the second song is one of the best soft, clean guitar parts ive ever heard, and the piano melody that drives the third song is one of the best piano melodies i've ever heard. If you wanna hear great music with an emphasis on melodic brilliance, and can get past the fact that the singer sings his amazing melodies in a foreign language (i think it is nordic, but ive rea that the singer sings in some language called \\"hopelandish\\", which surpirised me a lot. Someone please point out \\"hopeland\\" on the globe for me)then you will be truly pleased.  <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />There are some bands and some CDs that can completely, truly, and fully express an emotion or thought or idea. The releases by super insane speed kingpins Strapping Young Lad perfectly personifies true chaos, Van Halen and Limp Bizkit truly reflect true fun, Amnesiac by Radiohead truly personifies real loss, U2 truly express a true and fresh sense of wonder that comes with being a person on this planet,  and this untitled CD by Sigur Ros truly expresses serenity. Buy this and hear things as you see them at this time of year (for people who go back and read this review, i am writing this in Winter of 2005, Christmas Day is exactly one week). By the way, another CD that does a fantastic job of sonically representing the hopeful and occasionally sad side of winter is O.K. Computer by Radiohead. It is SUCH a winter sounding CD

B00005J6T0|5.0|True Blue is a great album, and presents some of Madonna's biggest hits. The best songs on it are \\"Open Your Heart\\",<br />\\"Papa Don't Preach\\", \\"White Heat\\" and \\"Love makes the world go round\\". Amongst the two singles Open your heart and Papa don't preach are \\"Live To Tell\\", \\"True Blue\\" and \\"La Isla Bonita\\".<br />Most of the album is lisenable apart from the throw away track \\"Jimmy,Jimmy\\". Overall it's a great album, and Madonna really evolved on this album. Two great remixes are included on this remastered version of True Blue.<br />Track by Track rating.<br />1. Papa Don't Preach.<br />This is a good song for Madonna, and an essential madonna hit.<br />This track is very well known. It has a good beat and is very fun to listen to. 5/5<br />2. Open Your Heart.<br />This is one of Madonna's greatest hits. The album version is great, but check out the 12 inch remix because it is even better. White Heat.<br />This song is equally as catchy as Open Your Heart and is a great pop song for this album. It could have probably been a single. It has a bit of monolouge at the beginning but is a great song. Like Open Your Heart it is very 80's sounding pop music. Makes you want to get up and dance. 5/5<br />4. Live To Tell.<br />This was one of Madonna's first serious ballads, and many people said it was her most beautiful song at this point in her career. It is quite a nice song, and fits in well with this album. Another hit. 4/5<br />5. Where's The Party.<br />This song was O.K. but I didn't find it particually catchy. This song sounded as if it belonged more on \\"You Can Dance\\", but I am glad they included it on the album. It is an attempt at a dance track from Madonna. It doesn't sound too bad, but it doesn't sound great either. 3/5.<br />6. True Blue.<br />This is the albums title track and is quite catchy, but does sound a lot like a song by a 60's girl group. I guess that's how it's supposed to sound. This was at the time another big hit for Madonna. Like Open Your Heart you may not instantly recognise the title, but you will recognise this song when you hear it. 4/5<br />7. La Isla Bonita.<br />This is a good song. It's probably one of the best latino sounding songs from the 1980's i've heard. It is full of rhythm and will make you want to get up and dance. This song is the most similar song to \\"Who's That Girl\\". It was also a big single from the album. 4/5.<br />8. Jimmy, Jimmy.<br />Like \\"Where's The Party\\" this song did not really catch my attention, and even though quite catchy at points this song was one of the albums filler tracks. Nothing rememberable. 2/5<br />9. Love Makes The World Go Round.<br />Some people found this song annoying, but I like it. It is a good song with an important message and I feel it is a better party track then \\"Jimmy, Jimmy\\" or \\"Where's The Party\\". It has a lot of latino flavour, and is quite energetic and good to dance to. Not a bad song. 4/5<br />10. True Blue - The Color Mix.<br />This is a colourful remix of the song ( as it's title implies ) and is better then the original. Warner Bros made a good choice including this track on the remastered version of \\"True Blue\\" 5/5<br />11. La Isla Bonita - Extended Remix.<br />Once again just like the True Blue remix this song has more beat then the original and is a better track. It has an extended intro and outro where the beat builds up and extra instrumental parts in it, and the beat is heavier. 5/5.<br />The sound quality of this album is great and differs in no way to any of todays albums. The cover Art is also fully restored to all it's glory, and is the exact same as the 1986 L.P. cover art.<br />Overall this album is worth the buy if your a fan of Madonna, and is one of her most vibrant and colourful works, churning out plenty of hits.e another big hit for Madonna. Like Open Your Heart you may not instantly recognise the title, but you will recognise this song when you hear it. 4/5  7. La Isla Bonita.  This is a good song. It's probably one of the best latino sounding songs from the 1980's i've heard. It is full of rhythm and will make you want to get up and dance. This song is the most similar song to \\"Who's That Girl\\". It was also a big single from the album. 4/5.  8. Jimmy, Jimmy.  Like \\"Where's The Party\\" this song did not really catch my attention, and even though quite catchy at points this song was one of the albums filler tracks. Nothing rememberable. 2/5  9. Love Makes The World Go Round.  Some people found this song annoying, but I like it. It is a good song with an important message and I feel it is a better party track then \\"Jimmy, Jimmy\\" or \\"Where's The Party\\". It has a lot of latino flavour, and is quite energetic and good to dance to. Not a bad song. 4/5  10. True Blue - The Color Mix.  This is a colourful remix of the song ( as it's title implies ) and is better then the original. Warner Bros made a good choice including this track on the remastered version of \\"True Blue\\" 5/5  11. La Isla Bonita - Extended Remix.  Once again just like the True Blue remix this song has more beat then the original and is a better track. It has an extended intro and outro where the beat builds up and extra instrumental parts in it, and the beat is heavier. 5/5.  The sound quality of this album is great and differs in no way to any of todays albums. The cover Art is also fully restored to all it's glory, and is the exact same as the 1986 L.P. cover art.  Overall this album is worth the buy if your a fan of Madonna, and is one of her most vibrant and colourful works, churning out plenty of hits.

B000641ZA4|5.0|If you were an avid watcher of MTV back in the '80s when it was still 'music television', there was no way to escape watching at least one, two or more Genesis videos during the day. The band was riding high during their second wave of success (post-Peter Gabriel) and they embraced making music videos wholeheartedly.<br /><br />With MTV and VH1 now seeming to show less music and more 'trash' (reviewers opinion), the \\"Genesis Video Show\\" DVD is a huge welcome treat and is a must for the avid Genesis fan.<br /><br />The collection spans the years 1976 to 1997 and includes every music video the band ever made during their career. It also shows the many sides to the band's personalities displaying humor (as with \\"Illegal Alien\\", \\"Invisible Touch\\", \\"Jesus He Knows Me\\", \\"I Can't Dance\\", \\"Anything She Does\\" and \\"Land Of Confusion\\"), intimacy (\\"Hold On My Heart\\", \\"Follow You Follow Me\\"), seriousness (\\"Mama\\", \\"No Son Of Mine\\", \\"Tonight Tonight Tonight\\") and pure musicianship (\\"Abacab\\", \\"Ripples\\", \\"Home By The Sea\\").<br /><br />The sound and picture quality of the DVD is amazing bringing out the music in a stunning new mix (courtesy of long-time producer Nick Davis) with crystal clear images. There are also individual credits for each video that can be displayed by hitting the start button on your DVD remote before the actual video begins.<br /><br />While the \\"Genesis Video Show\\" is a near perfect display of all the Genesis videos, there are a few downsides to the collection. First of all, the band's early days with Peter Gabriel are sadly underrepresented on this DVD - the 1999 version of \\"Carpet Crawlers\\" being the only Gabriel track here. While the band did not make any commercial promo clips or videos during the Gabriel-era, it would have been nice to have seen a vintage concert clip or two from this period. This also would've given a more complete picture of the band in this collection.<br /><br />The second flaw (which is a big one in this reviewers opinion) is in the video for \\"Man On The Corner\\" which was taken from the 1981 Abacab tour. The true version of the video is a live performance with the band actually playing the song on stage in real time. For the version on this DVD, the original picture is maintained but the studio album version is heard in place of the actual performance. This creates an awkward experience while watching this video because Phil's lyrics in the live version don't always match that of the studio version. Why this was done this way is a mystery and the video should have been left as is with its original live track in tact.<br /><br />Apart from these flaws, the \\"Genesis Video Show\\" is a fantastic journey down memory lane and is a great collection of videos from this most-loved band. Buy this DVD, sit back and enjoy the ride. It'll be like living in the '80s all over again.ner\\" which was taken from the 1981 Abacab tour. The true version of the video is a live performance with the band actually playing the song on stage in real time. For the version on this DVD, the original picture is maintained but the studio album version is heard in place of the actual performance. This creates an awkward experience while watching this video because Phil's lyrics in the live version don't always match that of the studio version. Why this was done this way is a mystery and the video should have been left as is with its original live track in tact. <br />Apart from these flaws, the \\"Genesis Video Show\\" is a fantastic journey down memory lane and is a great collection of videos from this most-loved band. Buy this DVD, sit back and enjoy the ride. It'll be like living in the '80s all over again.
